description:
Came in here to do some work on a Friday morning.

Great atmosphere! I'm not a local so I can't compare to other places nearby but it's chill and most people are being productive as well.

Almond milk latte was pretty standard and I got the blueberry crumbcake- also pretty standard.

They have a decent number of outlets so that's always a plus!
author: Benjamin L.

description:
I'll start of by saying this is my favorite coffee shop. The attention to detail and the assortment of pastries really make this place a hidden Gem among the sea of Coffee houses in SF. 

The coffee cake which tastes like it was made with the delicate hands of the Angels with a cappuccino that is expertly crafted to perfection is something I wish I could find on the east coast. 

My recommendation is get your order to stay. Let the ambiance soak in. The decor is that of an old ship, farmhouse and modern day architecture all blended together. The environment has helped me be productive while also giving me a sense of calm.

Anytime I'm in the Upper Haight or in SF, I make a special trip to Flywheel.
author: Elliot Z.

description:
I have been to this coffee house twice now and love it. All of the staff are lovely and helpful, and they make a great latte which is my drink of choice. I'm lactose and they have several milk substitute options including soy, almond and coconut. The only bummer (and this is something I've noticed at other coffee houses in San Francisco) is that they don't sell sizes here. Everything is the same tall/maybe grande cup size. I wish I could get something more!

The layout of Flywheel is huge. There are several large tables in front and an outdoor space as well with several more spots to sit down. Definitely a place you could come with large groups and you wouldn't feel guilty taking up space. I would also recommend coming here to do work or homework - lots of front window bar space and stools to sit. Even when it's busy, there are usually still a few open spots.

The menu of drinks is located on the whole and they also sell small food items/baked goods. I have never had anything to eat but I've been tempted by their savory items: pizza danish and ham and cheese croissant.

Open on Labor Day too which was nice because a few of my other regular spots were not. Must come here!
author: Bri T.

description:
A great find, right across from Golden Gate Park! SF has its fair share of hipster coffee shops, and Flywheel definitely meets the standard. The interior was very spacious, yet warm and cozy. There's lighting that will fit your mood: dim lighting in the back and plenty of natural lighting in front to enjoy your cup of coffee. There's plenty of small tables, and most people were either reading or on their laptops. The music played at a nice mellow level, so it'd be nice to study here!

I ordered a simple iced latte, and my friend got hers with almond milk. Both were delicious! The prices weren't too steep, considering the touristy location and prices of other SF coffee shops. There's also free side street parking, but could be difficult to find a spot. Overall, love the ambiance here!
author: Allison V.

description: Came here twice during my trip to San Fransisco. The staff is very friendly and the coffee is good. Their nitro is a bit bitter so it wasn't our favorite. I ended up ordering a latter and loving it. Cute little spot to grab a snap and coffee.
author: Denise C.

description: I'm definitely a bit of a coffee snob. This place has good reviews. I got an iced latte with almond milk. It was so, so disappointing. It was $5 including .50cents for the almond milk. I don't mind paying an additional charge for almond milk. However, when I got my drink, it looked like watery espresso. It had literally maybe a drizzle of almond milk, if that. Over half of the teeny cup was filled with ice and there was basically very little to drink. I felt ripped off. I was going to stay inside and work, but it was also incredibly hot and the atmosphere was not nice. Please stay away.
author: Lauren A.

description: Still one of my favorite places! The aesthetic of the shop is great and the coffee always tastes good. I got a latte with almond milk which is my go-to drink ($5).
author: Liza H.

description: Flywheel is always great coffee. I've come here on and off for the past 4 years, and now, I finally live within a short walking distance. Their staff is friendly as well as most of the customers that come in. I highly recommend trying their cold brew and literally any of their pastries. It's also conveniently next to Whole Foods and Golden Gate Park across the street.
author: Stephen S.

description:
I came here to study or do some work before work and grab a cold brew. There are side streets with free parking or 2 hour parking so pretty accessible. The 7 also runs through here (and probably other muni lines) 

This place has a lot of seats and high top bars (if you don't like sitting) and has a cool atmosphere! I really like the wood decor! The inside of the shop has pretty dim lighting so if you want good light, gotta sit by the windows with the high top bars. 

I really like my cold brews earthy, none of this nitro hipster stuff that's been going around lately where the cold brew tastes like water (yuck!). Flywheel's cold brew was earthy and flavorful! You could taste it entering your mouth and going down your throat and it was glorious! I guess you could say it tasted "strong" for lack of a better word, but it was good. If you don't like that, then you can let the ice melt a little to water it down, but that just dilutes the flavor!

One complaint is that you need to register to get onto their internet, either by email or facebook and I didn't like that. I would rather they have a secure connection with a password, but that's just me.

Probably would come back to study on the way to work or school.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
This place is amazing!  Excellent coffee in a beautiful, spacious setting.  The enclosed back patio is lovely and this place is baby-friendly, too. (The changing table in the bathroom was a pleasant surprise and much appreciated!).  

Yay!  So glad to have found this spot.
author: Barnali D.

description: This is my local coffee spot and I'm pretty into it! The coffee is good, there tends to be a fair amount of dogs both inside and outside, and there's a variety of seating options from tables to shared tables to a backyard type spot and even some benches out front. I kinda wish they had something other than baked goods but perhaps it's better to not fix what isn't broken. The service is particularly friendly.
author: Misha T.

description: So glad I stumbled upon this cute coffee shop! The employees take their time to provide quality coffee and I was surprised when they said "bye Michaela" as I left. You don't get that at Starbucks! Will be coming back next time in SF
author: Michaela O.

description:
Hands down best hot chocolate ive ever had. This place is super cool, trendy, and fun. Right by GG park it's a good pit stop in the day. 

I loved the overall vibe and the friendliness of the staff. 

What else is there to add? Oh yeah the coffee was great (well hot cocoa cuz I didn't have coffee...) but I've heard it's good
author: Marissa R.

description:
I don't really have sophisticated/discerning tastes when it comes to coffee, but I enjoyed coming to this cafe! The interior is spacious with lots of seats (although it was still hard to find a table when I came on a Sunday afternoon) and it has a really cute back patio area. Unfortunately there's only one bathroom and the wifi is a little spotty/slow, but the relaxed ambiance makes up for it. 

I thought the customer service was really good! The barista took the time to recommend a brew that he thought I would enjoy based on what I said I liked in coffee (not acidic, more chocolate/nutty flavors) and they let me have almond milk to mix into my coffee for no extra charge (I feel like so many coffee shops charge an additional +$0.50-1.00 for non-dairy milks!). 

Good place to come relax for an afternoon.
author: Melissa H.

description: This place is great!  Great coffee, beautiful big open space, super friendly baristas.  This place is doing everything right.  I wish it was closer to my place so I could come more often.  Lots of tables, seating, free wifi and outlets.  It has a really good vibe.  Really enjoyed coming here.  It's also right by the park so it's great to take a walk and then sit by the window.
author: Lisa O.

description:
Not a coffee connoisseur but an avid coffee drinker. Good cup of latte here with plenty of seating. Unfortunately, WiFi didn't work for me although it worked for my friend. (Side note: you log in using your FB or email as opposed to a password.) 

In addition to good coffee, they had tons of Halloween spirit with costumes and Halloween themed music. Will def be back if I'm in the area.
author: Angie Y.

description:
Great staff
Comfy outdoor area
Service dog friendly
Yummy pastries 
Great spot next to Whole Foods
author: scott c.

description:
Another place proudly serves Siphon coffee that I only realized when I finished my cappuccino. Should have seen the big equipment behind the barista! Having said that, I did quite enjoy my small cup of capp. Aside from regular coffee, they also have cold brew, nitro and affogato. 

Very good for a short rest as it was just next to the park. That big piece of croissant looked so attractive too!

SanFran's really got tons of decent coffee shops!
author: Elaine H.

description:
I went here last week to work with my laptop. 

Perks of the space:
1. Free wifi
2. Overall large space with tables. Definitely the biggest cafe I have been to in San Francisco.
3. Small outdoor patio area
4. Plenty of outlets
5. Right across from the park and all the cool shops on Haight.

This tops the list for best cafes to work from.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Nice coffee in general, prefer pour over over the siphon. The siphon does look madly cool though :-) Ethiopia beans are super delicious....

7/17/2018 Update 
I like this place in general, and have been here almost every time I stop by at Amoebas. I have been biting my tongue quite a bit lately, but I guess it is time to say something. The quality of coffee is still relatively high and i would still stand by the recommendation for their own roasted beans. However, the quality of the staff has been going down. The lady that took our order has the "I hate my job" look on full display on her face, listless and borderline "why-are-you-making-me-work" kind of rude. The dude behind the counter was in a zone by himself, sauntering and grooving from station to station almost aimlessly because of his glacial pace despite the long line. I suspect he is still coming down from "a higher ground" :-) and kudos to the one barista that prepared out drinks who was busting his rear-end to push out orders. I love this place, hopefully, things will get better.
author: Opus O.

description:
Flywheel is decently large, but the day I came with a few others, we were scattered throughout the cafe as it was nearly impossible to be seated together. If you're perching at a high counter or posting at a small table by yourself, there isn't so much an issue of space. So remember, good for one, difficult for more.

On a spectrum of acidic to not, the spectrum which I realize is different for each coffee drinker, the beans here tend to be on the more acidic side. But go from coffee to espresso and the acidity becomes more nuanced, perhaps hidden by the frothy milk. Not good or bad per say, but really just a footnote in taste.

There's a small outdoor section in the back with 3 or so small tables meant for parties of 2. On the side are 2 benches if you'd like to get some quiet time or have an intimate chat with a friend.
author: Cici T.

description:
In need of a little pick me up and place to catchup, I found myself here at Flywheel Coffee Roasters. Next to a whole foods and directly across the street from Golden Gate Park, you can take your coffee during your stroll through the grocery market or park! This shop is really spacious which is much appreciated when you're surrounded by the constantly cramped spaces of SF. Keep walking towards the back, there is also some seating ouside! 

Unfortunately I didn't yelp this place beforehand, so I didn't know they were known for their cold brew, nitro, and siphon. I ended up getting an iced mocha which tasted great, really deep chocolatey flavors. Didn't notice too many outlets, so I'm not sure if it's the greatest place for studying unless you're coming with a fully charged laptop. Solid visit, but I need to come back for some cold brew for sure.
author: Maleah M.

description:
For what you pay: overpriced.
Ambiance: sick! Reason alone to go
Service: slow and steady for average taste
Taste: okay


This little coffee shop caught my attention yesterday morning. Road bicyclists lined up for the morning boost of epinephrine their athletic feats didn't give them. They group together around large ornate seating arrangements and impress upon the the public eye a warning of stronger than your average joe coffee.  So it seems with any coffee shop that is in an abundance of cyclists in the morning!  While this place truly speaks for itself in taste and ambiance I will say it is not a place to pop in to get a hot chocolate to go. I waited 20 minutes for it. I was expecting it to be great and was let down by the mediocrity of it.  This seems like the type of place you DONT get coffee to go. Maybe next time I'll come here to practice what Millennials and generations alike us call a "productive day" where we pay 2-3$ for coffee and suck up the shops Wifi for an indefinite amount of time. This shop DOES seem like the place to do that!!!
author: Rob C.

description: Lovely coffee joint.  Coffee excellent, baristas highly competent and fun.  Scene positive with great 'regulars.'
author: Bill V.

description: I was doing the touristy thing through Golden Gate Park and noticed this spot as I was leaving.  I hadn't consumed nearly enough caffeine by the time I got there post morning rush around 9:30am, and opted for an almond milk iced mocha to go. I was surprised only one size was an option - and that cup looked pretty darn small.  I believe the price was $4.95, which when filled with ice made for a drink that was probably only worth $3.95 (yes, even in SF).  It was a decent iced mocha, though, so a solid 4 stars for me.
author: Amber S.

description:
Pretty cool coffee stop to sip and scroll online. Just coffee and pastries.
Plenty of seating in the front as well as the back (even a small outdoor patio area).
Very clean and one restroom inside.
And an accessible water faucet to refill.
author: Anisa A.

description:
Noise Level: Mellow Background Music 
Ambience: Dim Lighting with natural light from windows
Drinks: Mainly Coffee 
Wifi: Yes, but insecure network 
Seating: 10+ tables, seats approximately 40 people
Bathroom: Yes
Parking: Difficult, near Haight a tourist/hangout spot
Overall: 7/10 for Studying and Working
author: Angela L.

description:
This is a really neat and hip coffee shop right by the UCSF campus and right across the street from Golden Gate Park. When I first walked into the shop, it gave off a really chill and hip vibe to it. There's plenty of seats and tables for people to do work at or just hang out and socialize. It's also spacious too, so there's enough room for the many people that are standing waiting for their drinks or if you prefer to stand altogether. 

If you get a chance to watch your drink being brewed, you definitely should! They use these interesting looking holders to brew your drink in. It looks like your drink is going through a chemical reaction. Coffee usually tastes really strong for me, however, when I tried some of the brew here, it was almost perfect for me. I didn't have to add any additional sugar. The coffee here has a nice, fragrant, and flavorful taste and scent to it. It's also pretty legit how everyone you talk to here is super chill and down to earth. Good coffee, good company!
author: Brandon D.

description:
Friendly staff. Strong decaf latte (they put an extra shot free). Sunny window from which to view GGP across the street and tourists/local folks stroll by. What more could you want?
Ok, maybe tasty pastries (try the chocolate biscotti). Check. Reasonable prices. Check.  Music, but not too loud. Check.
Check it out.
author: Liana T.

description: Excellent americano, not too weak and coffee flavor was intricate and smooth.  Service was stellar.  Despite it being the end of the day, the staff was personable, kind, curious, quick, and conscientious of everyones needs.  I was particularly amazed that the staff could remain that way in the hustle and bustle of the Haight.  I was burnt out just trying to find somewhere to work on my laptop in that area, so I was very impressed they were able to remain kind and open after, what I imagine, must be a lot of "interesting" customers coming in all day.  Thanks and I'll be back for sure!
author: Emma L.

description:
Working in Flywheel instantly gives you cool points. It's just that hipster.

Came here to crank out some work on a weekend. Ordered an almond milk latte and the nitro (not at the same time). The espresso was super dark and flavorful-- I'm not used to being able to taste the flavor notes of espresso in my lattes, but I was able to here! If you like sweet lattes, this won't jive well with you, but I thought it tasted delicious. The nitro was tasty as well and definitely over-caffeinated me. Honestly, I've had better nitro, but for around $5 it's not a bad deal.

Once you order your coffee, there's a good variety of seating options to take (small 2 person tables with a booth, long tables with tall stools, etc etc). There's also a small patio out in the back if you want some sunshine. From the looks of the crowd, it seems like most people who opt to order their coffee "for here" are busy at work on their macbooks. The use of macbooks might be the pre-requisite for fitting in at Flywheel, but is also necessary as there is a definite lack of outlets.

There is free wifi-- it turns off after a certain amount of time, but you can always ask the staff for another access code. There is also free water, but the mason jars you use as a cup are pretty tiny. During the 3+ hours there, the amount of customers varied, but the line was never more than 4 people deep.

Overall, a pretentious coffee bar, but you gotta love it. Good coffee, hip vibe, and a calming place to settle down and pound out work.
author: Angela C.

description: I'm a coffee snob. But come on, I'm a working guy. So I'm a snob on a budget.  And this is my go to place for buying the beans I use to aeropress the coffee I drink at home almost every day. Yes I love the fantastic single origins at Blue Bottle and 4 Barrel and Ritual and my overall favorite Andy Town, but I've paid more than $30 for a (fantastic) 12 oz. bag of beans before at these places.  And a lot of times it's totally worth it to get these wonderful and exotic flavors. But day-to-day I go here to buy the beans I grind fresh every morning. Price just went up to $19 for a 16 oz bag,  but it's still what I believe to be the best value in town for single origin coffee beans. And if you pay with square up they have rewards. And they are nice people who brew a solid cappuccino also!  So stick your pinky out and drink deeply of the bargain brews at this Upper Haight area roaster.
author: Kelly P.

description:
Great vibe, location, black coffee!! Flywheel checks all the important coffee criteria for me. Drinks are $4 and up and they make a solid pour-over and cold brew. I like my coffee dark and dank and they did not disappoint. Quality beans, roast, and prep technique. Loved the salsa playlist they had when I was there. 

The only place it is lacking is seating availability. Naturally it's popular and crowded and can be hard to get a spot. Consider getting your coffee to go and popping over the Golden Gate Park to enjoy it.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Not a fan of the coffee I've decided, it tastes oily. The staff is courteous & professional but I just don't get it. And at 4 bucks a pop for a regular coffee, I'm trying elsewhere.
author: Henry K.

description:
Is the coldbrew supposed to be sour? 

Got the nitro coldbrew and it particularly did not sit with my stomach very well. I thought maybe it was just something unique to the experience of the "siphon filter" coffee. From what I have researched, sourness and acidity comes from under roasting coffee or having cold brew sit in a warm area for too long causing it to go rancid. 

Definitely not an expert in brewing coffee, but I would at least would like the person making the coffee know something about the sour taste. I was curious so I legitimately asked the gentleman, "do you know what makes the sour taste in the coffee?"

He replied back with, "I don't know" in a 'don't bother me' attitude. The fellow at the register was a little off putting too. I asked him what "nitro" on the menu meant. He told me it's iced coffee with nitro. I followed up with, "so is it iced coffee or is it cold brew?" Looking confused and annoyed, he replied, "yeah it's cold brew". 

Sooooo, is it cold brew or is it iced coffee?

All about 2nd chances, I'm not gonna go on a rampage here and I usually don't write reviews unless I had a good experience. The personal experience that I had was just a little inconsistent with what I have read here. Would love to experience it again sometime - though I am not a resident.
author: Yves D.

description: One of the best coffee shops in the Bay Area. Incredibly nice and friendly staff. Lots of hipster space to do work. Good, strong coffee. Great location by the park.
author: Jeff M.

description: Good coffee and cosy environment. Was there to catch up with a friend of mine. Definitely a place for coffee and to hangout!
author: Vinteng N.

description:
Flywheel has some of the best dark roast coffee I have ever had. I don't pretend to be or not to be a coffee snob but I am constantly surprised at the consistency of their pour over coffee. 

To the newbie coffee drinker and lay person, they have a pretty cool selection of coffee using different brew methods. It's not cheap to say the least with a basic cup at $4. But that's SF right? However, that black cup of Ethiopia blend containing hints of blueberry and chocolate is carefully crafted via pour over instead of the standard drip coffee. 

Not only is their pour over awesome, but the HIGHLIGHT must be their nitro cold brew. I detest cold caffeine, but their cold brew honestly made me give iced coffee a chance. Sadly, no cold brew has made me swoon like theirs, therefore, I'll be sticking to flywheel. With a selection of amazing pastries, flywheel has everything: so much space from the front, tall tables offering copious natural light to the tables situated right across from the brewing action to the back room and patio perfect for larger groups. I often stop by and hunker down to compose emails and to get some serious studying done. 

A small caveat is that it is one of THE most hipster coffee shops I have ever been to with special siphon contraptions and the aesthetic architecture and vaulted ceilings. Plus the amount of testosterone pulsing through... from the very nice and friendly baristas to techie, bearded men on laptops is hilarious. In terms of laptop accomodations: very limited/sparse outlets but the wifi is free (fogfree) and can be somewhat spotty- but I, fortunately, have unlimited mobile hot spot.
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
+2 stars for the smooth pour over (ethiopian) that didn't go bitter or become too acidic...

-3 stars for the horde of children running up and down the length of the cafe. thanks parents, for never saying "no" to your kids... and thanks to the staff that just let the kids wreak havoc. cool.
author: Lorraine Y.

description: I ordered an iced macchiato and when I received an espresso shot in ice, they made me pour my own milk. The barista then proceeded to tell me I need to learn how to order better because I'm using the wrong amount of milk and wasting their milk. Then turned to the other barista and said "is that something they have at Starbucks or something" and gave me a dirty look. They have terrible service and no respect for their customers.
author: Gloria B.

description:
Glad I broke my siphon coffee cherry here.

We saw siphon coffee in Japan but we never got to try it, but ever since we came back, we've been dying to try it. The lady at the counter was nice to help guide us through the process and explain everything. We also had the chance to watch her make it--which was the fun part. The coffee was bright and had a lot of clarity. It wasn't very acidic and had notes of chocolate. 

All in all, was a great experience. I'm glad I came.
author: David Z.

description: The perfect place to grab coffee or a snack. The service is great and very friendly. There is plenty of space to work or hang out. No complaints on the coffee and the pastries we sampled were great!
author: Brittany A.

description:
This is my favorite coffee place in SF. I tend to draw a distinction between a great cup of coffee and a cup of joe. A cup of joe usually tastes the same and gives me fuel to keep going. It's drip, batch brew or diner coffee.

When I get the pour over at Flywheel, it's completely different. It's much more delicate and nuanced than the drip I usually subsist on. You can really taste the floral, nutty or earthy notes, depending which bean you choose. It's really my weekend treat.

On top of that the service is nice and they have coffee cake.
author: Andrew P.

description: I love this place!! Lots of seating, friendly staff and very good coffee! Spacious clean bathroom as well! I got the mocha cappuccino which was really strong and less chocolatey which was surprisingly good and i also got the morning glory tea cake which wasn't anything special especially since they can't warm up any of there baked goods but other than that I will definitely come here again:)
author: Alyssa J.

description: My new favorite coffee joint in SF! The back patio is a hidden gem! I love to sit in some warmth and sunshine with their coffee... which is possibly the best I've tasted in San Francisco. Staff are friendly and prices are reasonable!
author: Leah F.

description: Mmmmmm. Strong espresso almost chocolatey in nature. I absolutely love sitting out on their back patio. It's partially shaded and a lovely place to do work. Also, inside has plentiful seating for studying or getting together with a group. They also have very cool coffee equipment to ogle at. Highly recommend for coffee lovers
author: Mary Kate R.

description: Just got the best soy mocha in recent memory from the barista here this morning. Great way to end 2017 and looking forward to more of these beauties in 2018.
author: Vicki H.

description:
As much as I love a good cup of joe, I'd be lying if I said I was a coffee connoisseur.  While I can easily tell the difference between the likes of Blue Bottle, Starbucks, and the "coffee" from those Keurid pods (both gross and an environmental menace), my palette definitely isn't sophisticated enough to pick up on the nuances of grinds and beans from around the world.  However, if I were to spend more time at a place like Flywheel?  Perhaps I could start!

Similar to the likes of Blue Bottle and so many of the city's other "hipster coffee shops", Flywheel is quite a bit nicer than your typical neighborhood spot.  The space is decently large and spacious with a modern commercial/industrial sort of look.  Their relative wealth of tables and high tops also make them a good spot for camping out, but all of the meters and restrictions on nearby parking put a damper on that.  Most importantly though, the coffee is pretty good!

Offering beans from numerous countries of the world, Flywheel features a variety of coffee that you don't often see.  Of the handful of choices available, I opted to go with the TARRAZU from Costa Rica ($4.00) specifically because I wanted to see if it tasted like what I had when I was down there (it kind of did!).  While it wasn't super strong, it still packed some punch (hellooooo, caffeine!) and had a nice profile - deep, dark, and a tinge of caramel that was quite tasty.

To go with my cup of lava java, I also decided to try their CINNAMON CRUMB CAKE ($3.50).  Of all of the pastries in the case, this stood out to me the most simply because it looked so good!  And believe me when I say that it tasted even better; the crumble on top was awesome (not super heavy on the cinnamon) and the cake itself was so moist and light.  Plus, it wasn't overly sweet either, which made it just that much better.

Besides the area's parking situation, Flywheel might not be the ideal option for camping out for an extended period unless you happen to be near one of the few outlets I saw (though, to be fair, I didn't make a point of looking).  However, if you're just looking for a place to catch up with friends or to check out their coffees?  Flywheel just might be what you're looking for.  I'm sure I'll be back again, especially for that crumb cake and to try the cold brew that so many others have mentioned!
author: Mike L.

description: Attractive ambience. Adequate seating space. Great place to come and sturdy. Great location for grabbing coffee before the park near Hippie Hill, and friendly baristas. The flavor of the coffee wasn't all that though, especially for being a roster. Seemed flavorless :/ I would come back and try something else though, not the latte.
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
The good: 
1. The coffee tasted amazing - I've only had the Mocha. I plan on tasting more of the menu 
2. The place is spacious. It can comfortably seat 60 people. 
3. Latte art - you will get some type of creative design with the steamed milk that tops your espresso. 
4. This place roasts their coffee themselves

The bad: 

1. Not many outlets 
2. Small portions -  I felt like I ordered an entree and got the quantity of an appetizer. 
3. Coffee potency - I didn't get much of a kick. I would say that the coffee strength lies somewhere in between Starbucks and Peet's. Albeit, this can be tied to the small portions. 

Overall, I had a good experience and I will be coming back. I would recommend this place to whoever is in the area and wants to enjoy a cup of coffee. I wouldn't recommend coming here with little battery life on your laptop.
author: Lance H.

description:
One of my best friends had the day off work, so he picked me up on his scooter, and we headed to Flywheel Coffee Roasters to chill. This is one of his go-to spots for a caffeine boost and quiet time to read. I didn't find anything particularly special about the coffee, though it's apparently famous for it's siphon, nitro brew, and other neat contraptions.

It's a lovely and relatively spacious café to hang out. Also right next to Golden Gate Park. Fortunately it wasn't too crowded when we came here on a random Tuesday afternoon, so we sat on one of the benches in the back. Flywheel has some tasty looking pastries and cakes that I didn't have a chance to try, so I definitely want to come back specifically for those. I'm looking forward to coming here again! I'd say it's one of my more memorable coffeeshop experiences in San Francisco.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
THE WIFI SUCKS! My friend and I came here to plan our vacation, and we couldn't access the wifi for 20 minutes! We kept having to refresh our page and it still didn't work, even after we validated the email! This is huge for me. If a coffee shop doesn't have good wifi, it's not even worth going (no matter how good the coffee is).

The coffee really is amazing, but I probably won't come back unless I just want coffee or I don't need wifi.
author: Remy B.

description: My most favorite coffee house in the city.The coffee is great, pretty strong and aromatic. The ambiance is very chill, great place to study or work. Free wifi and also GREAT staff!!!
author: rachel n.

description:
You gotta try this coffee! The roasts are so fragrant and flavorful, it's unreal. And the staff? Awesome, friendly, and they give the best customer service.
I will definitely be returning when I'm in the area again someday.
author: Ariel M.

description:
All you physicians out there should beware!
According to the barista ( baristo? it was a dude...) if you get Flywheel coffee to go it will 'harm the flavor.' So ya know, you took the Hippocratic Oath and I know you wouldn't want to do any harm, so you need to drink it there.

Hypocritically ( he he) they do have 'to go' cups...not sure why tho when it's so egregious to put your caffeine in a paper cup.

So.... now you're gonna obey the commandment and drink it on site. You will note the cold lab-like experience. A little alchemist-ish,  with hyper-styled ( sorta steampunk) coffee makers, which were  pretty much just percolators  rebranded as 'syphons.' But the baristo will swirl the coffee for you as if it were fine wine. 

Whatever. It didn't taste that great, and I'm not a fan of pretentious.
author: El B.

description:
Amazing coffee, great flavor. I had their Ethiopian roast and it was delicious as well as their bread with carrot and zucchini which I cannot remember the name for but it was also very good, exactly what I wanted. 

They have a good amount of seating as well and it's nice ambiance in there.
author: Ellie R.

description:
Probably my favorite coffeehouse in the neighborhood. The coffee is really good and vibe is nice for conversation or just studying. Generally super crowded; there's also an outside area with a few tables. I wish it were open a bit longer! 

I had the peanut butter power bar today and it was not that good haha, but got my protein in!
author: Juliana P.

description: Very cool place. It's got quite the character with plenty of space, welcoming baristas, and a rustic touch with some dope coffee drip happening in the back. Great place to meet up especially before a morning stroll through the Golden Gate Park right across the street.
author: Dion L.

description: I know everyone seems to be raving about the hot chocolate here, but I really wanted coffee. I couldn't decide what to get, but as I was browsing through their menu, I noticed a "Cortado"  not knowing what it was...I googled it and it's basically espresso with warm milk. So kind of like a latte, but smaller? I think it's kind if pricey for the amount you get, but it tastes really good! It seemed kind of busy today so seating was hard to find. I like that it's close to golden gate park and haight st! Def a nice place to go to for a quick cup of coffee. I'll definitely have to come back to try the siphon and hot chocolate :)
author: Crystal T.

description: Very cool space with a variety of seating options. Coffee was tasty and dark, but found their food to be dry. Prepare yourself for a line too.
author: Laurisha C.

description:
Great place to grab coffee. 
Great place to get work done.
Great place to buy whole fresh roasted beans to go.
Coffee runs $16 for 16ounces of whole bean or ground coffee that is usually roasted no more than 3-4 days before you buy it. They have a wide variety of coffee to buy, from multiple regions like Ethiopia, Columbia, etc. You can order an individual pour over cup or pound to go from any region.
Great place to get a pastry like a biscotti or banana bread.
Great Baristas that do a great job all around.
We have the perfect cafe! 
Sweet cafes like this are one of the many reasons people like me live in a place like this.
author: Michael P.

description:
Nice space, great proximity to the park.  Lots of space to work or meet.

I see siphon, pour over and Kyoto cold drippers.  I had a super fruity espresso.  I enjoyed it, but wonder how it pairs with milk.
author: Jane D.

description:
The first time, I had one of the best almond milk lattes made by this rockstar female barista. However, when I came yesterday, I had the most burned latte; it even smelled burned. I should have had it remade but honestly, some baristas don't know that they're burning almond milk so they make the same late again and again and I didn't want to burst his bubble.

Would probably not return. There should be some consistency here...
author: Monica J.

description:
Ordered two pour overs ($4) at 6:15 am in the morning, bright and early!

Staff was very kind and welcoming despite it being the crack of dawn. There is a parking lot for whole foods next door, if you're going to swing by for a cup on the go. 

They have their own roaster in house plus plenty of seating all around. Great place to meet up and hang around if you got the time.
author: Brian L.

description: It's great had a great time loved the nitro coffee and there's some art stuff that you can look at when you're inside the place where the coffee is served.
author: June C.

description:
Pro:
Spacious and hipster cafe where people can study and socialize while enjoying their coffee!

Con:
The flat white was good but it was more on the bitter side. You also have to register to use wifi.
author: Linda K.

description: Great mocha. Delicious coffee. Love that they'll let me swing by with my pup to grab a coffee before we go to the park. You think the staff are hipster, but they're actually really friendly and nice.
author: Celie H.

description:
I wanted to try this place for a while because it has san francisco hipster written all over it and looks really cool inside. I got a cappuccino and thought it was fine. Good, but nothing I'd travel far for. 

I guess the 3 stars are for how long it took and the not terribly friendly service. My boyfriend asked a question about what they were doing/what was going on (referring to the crazy science experiment coffee set up they have) and the barista didn't really provide an answer, he kinda just said he was making coffee or something "duhhh" like that.
author: Kelly G.

description: Very hipster. The space has a cool, spare industrial vibe, but the seats are uncomfortable. Very dog friendly. All the baristas have three day stubble. You're expected to have strong preferences between Guatemalan and Ethiopian beans. I would be enthusiastic about this (all but the seats) except I didn't really like the coffee, which I thought was weak and grainy.
author: Ira S.

description:
Flywheel looks like it was plucked right out of a hip late-twentysomething's fantasy. To put it simply, it's just an interesting place that emanates ~cool~.

Right upon walking into Flywheel, I was mesmerized by the scientific/industrial minimalist design of the interior. Very simple, but very functional and beautiful. Though certainly a popular coffeeshop, it isn't too loud, so this place would be absolutely perfect to study/work with quick breaks to people watch. That is, if you don't think you'll be too distracted by the beautiful-looking pastries in the main case.

If you're serious about your coffee, then the place is really awesome. But if you're expecting some super sweet, artificial vanilla-caramel-mocha-frap-latte-whatever, then I don't think you'll like the drinks at Flywheel all too much. I ordered a regular latte that was very good and clearly super high quality, but I think that it was maybe a little too intense for me. The more I sipped it, though, the more I began to like and appreciate it. I also had a sip of my friend's breve, which was good but also much stronger that I'm used to. I noticed that there definitely appeared to be a split between my friends, with the more serious coffee lovers enjoying their drinks much more so than the rest of us that view coffee as just a casual treat. 

Despite me (much to my chagrin) having to add extra sugar to my latte, I like Flywheel. It's nice to taste what good, pure coffee is supposed to be (especially at their really great prices). But with their small niche menu, it isn't a spot for everyone, especially if you're used to coffee drinks tasting more like dessert.
author: Desiree S.

description:
This review is just for the coffee. It's great. May have even gotten better.

I come here at least once a week. Best coffee in the city - only ritual really compares.

It's great to have seen this place grow over time and have their space well utilized on weekdays and weekends.

It's of the best coffee in SF, and the absolute best in a mile radius.
author: Ross H.

description:
Less than impressed

Everything in here looks so cool and it's really awesome that they roast their own beans. Personally, I think the coffee I ordered, the Nitro, was way too bitter and tasted like the end of the barrell. I could feel my stomach turning after a few small sips of this acidic brew. 

Other than the Siphons and that being a really funky means to brew coffee, I wouldn't come back here.
author: Kendal Ann M.

description:
Coffee is great. Atmosphere is chilly, dim, and consists of every single seat occupied by a twenty-something staring at a laptop. Between the keyboard-click punctuated silence and the subtle blue glow lighting everyone's face, we have taken to calling this place 'the morgue.' 

Again: coffee great; atmosphere super depressing. 

Also, no plain ol' drip coffee, only $4 pour-over or $6 'siphon' which looks fun but expensive.
author: Jaso M.

description:
Food/Drinks:
Above average coffee and pastries.

Nonsensical space:
Small ass tables and few outlets. I suppose you're encouraged to bring your hula hoop to make use of the giant warehouse space.

Experience:
Unaccommodating for work, not enough catch for hangout.

Wifi:
007 level complexity for establishing a coffee shop wifi connection.

Too hipster for me.
author: Tian Q.

description:
Flywheel Coffee
SF The Haight
2pm Wednesday 15th April 2015
Four Stars 

Flywheel to me is an exercise facility. It is also an app for you find and pay for a taxi. Now it's a coffee house as well. This place was very spacious but was too warm for me sit inside (probably because they actually roast beans inside the place. I had an iced coffee to wash away the taste of this mornings not so good ice coffee at earth's coffee. The coffee had notes of caramel and very low acidity. Enjoyable.
author: Leonard L.

description:
Paid $4.50 for sour cold brew. 

Atmosphere was the redeeming quality & the reason for 2 stars
author: Julia N.

description: One of my new favorite coffee houses.  Great coffee + wifi = productivity.  They also had a great ambience. It was quiet and relaxed. The no lay downside is you need a Mac to go here j/k. I did find it amusing that everyone there was on a Mac. I'll definitely be going out of my way to go here again.
author: Mike S.

description:
Keanu here is awesome and so kind! I came in one night after inquiring about their Nitrobrew on the phone. He was so nice and friendly both on the phone and in person.

He even let me sample the cold brew to compare it with the Nitrobrew. Both were amazing!

Great experience, amazing coffee and wonderful service. I definitely recommend trying Flywheel!
author: Leah B.

description: Nice place to grab a coffee and chat with a friend or work. It is fairly small so it might be hard to find seating for a group of more than 3 people. It is also pretty popular so seating can be hard generally. I also thought the menu was a little small and didn't have enough options. I was never disappointed with what I ordered though.
author: Jesse S.

description:
Came in on a Friday afternoon around 3pm to get some work done. I was scared that it would be really crowded and there wouldn't be any open seats, but it was actually pretty empty! The space is considerably large and there are outlets throughout the shop, so Flywheel could be a go-to spot if you're looking for a place to work or study on the weekdays.

After a few moments of contemplating, I decided to get the Siphon just because it's not something you see every day. It was cool to see them make the coffee, and they bring it to you in the pot for you to pour into the accompanying glass mug. The coffee itself was pretty mellow in flavor; it wasn't very bold, so if you're into stronger-tasting coffee then this probably isn't the best option for you. I did enjoy it myself, as it is definitely a unique way to experience coffee. I don't think I'd get it again simply because of the hefty price tag, but it was fun to try. On top of having a unique selection of drinks, the pastry case was loaded with goodies, but I wasn't hungry during my visit so I didn't get anything to eat even though everything looked so good.

I didn't get to try their cappuccino, which I use as my comparison point between coffee shops, so I'm a little hesitant to give Flywheel a full five stars. Hopefully I'll come back soon with an updated review!
author: Sabrina C.

description: So blown away by this coffee shop! Being from vegas I was so intrigued by the detail and process coffee is made.. from steam brewed to cold press to siphon.. I had no idea there was so many ways that make something as simple as coffee! I had no idea how what the siphon machine was so the gentleman there took his time to give me an in detail description of how the process works! Who knew only brewing the outside of the grains made the coffee extremely floral and so much less bitter?!?! I sure didn't. It was super nice of him to go out of his way and tell me step by step and why the coffee shop as made the way it was. The inside of the store is as very well put together and really spacious. I loved the decor and the space felt wide open but comforting at the same time. Coffee, service, and layout were all 6 out of 5 stars!
author: Chadwick G.

description: Love coming here when I'm in town. I'm not into buying coffee like this on the daily, but on vacation, I love it. Large inside area and right next door to Whole Foods.
author: K M.

description:
I love this spit for their amazing coffee and the pastries are a real treat especially the ' morning glory cake'.
A great spot to work, not noisy and plenty if space.
author: Philippa B.

description: Visited Flywheel this morning for a cup of coffee. I had a sample of the Nitro, which was crazy strong, yet delicious. As I am not a native of the city I wasn't aware that the Nitro was only served cold. I was in the mood for hot coffee so I ordered the Samoan roast. The coffee was great and quite strong. Everyone was nice and helpful with suggestions. I definitely recommend this place.
author: Nicole C.

description: This place is a little bit of a letdown the roasting their own coffee however the coffee quality is just average and the service is below average.  Unfortunately it's probably the best coffee in the area
author: Samuel G.

description:
Loved stopping by this coffee shop before heading to the panhandle / golden gate park. A few different seating areas, including an outdoor patio. Tried their mocha and iced latte, mocha was very good and I kept getting it. Also tried their pastry, strawberry morning cake was tasty with coconut flavor.

The only thing I hope could be better was the wifi. Had some hard time connecting for a few times, their sign in page just wouldn't work (Whole foods's wifi was available and I found it more reliable :p)
author: Jaclyn C.

description: Went here to study one afternoon!  It does get crowded but they do have outdoor seating.  I had a latte and it was pretty strong so I had to add a little cream.  I tried some of their pastries and they were okay.  I liked the donut more.  If you're looking for a study spot, this is a great option!
author: Mikayla M.

description:
I came here with some friends to get some work done, and I got a latte while here. I thought the latte was okay, not that great because it had more milk than I usually prefer. We sat at a round table in the back, and I liked how this place is a lot bigger than it looks. 

I would rather come here to meet up with someone rather than get work done since I found it kind of on the louder side.
author: Steph V.

description:
I really enjoyed studying here yesterday. I ordered a macchiato, and since I only had a macchiato from Starbucks before, I didn't realize it was so small at first lol. I really liked it! I'm looking forward to trying some more coffee

I like the atmosphere, and everyone from employee to customer is polite. Everyone there is pretty much there to do work, and drink coffee. You may occasionally see a child, stroller or dog, but the place is so spacious, it won't bother you at all if this is a usually negative for you. 

At a busy time of day, I can bring my stuff to study and potentially not get a seat, and because I live and work on the other side of SF, that would suck for me...
author: Kristal R.

description: Awesome, awesome coffee shop! Wish I lived closer. The industrial vibe is nicely contrasted against the park across the street. The coffee was remarkable and I was able to find a table after a few minutes of lingering.
author: Slater K.

description: Quiet space, good music, no waiting for seating, and friendly service. I was able to read and actually get work done so thumbs up for me.
author: Jackie T.

description:
This place is perfect for those seeking on setting aside time for productivity. It is also a great place to socialize since the caffe is so spacious. Upon entering, the overall atmosphere and vibe of Flywheel Coffee Roasters is great. The decor is fairly modern and very hip. 

The coffee itself is has good flavor for those who don't prefer the extremes- not too sweet, not too bitter.
author: Grace Z.

description: I been wanting to try Flywheel for a while. The cafe itself was very spacious and dim. But I think it was all hype. I order their regular latte and banana bread. Nothing special about the coffee itself. I ha better lattes else where. And the coffee art was not even nice. If you are charging me for a 5 dollar latte, at least give me some pretty art? haha But the banana bread was pretty good.
author: Sandy B.

description: Moved into the neighborhood a few weeks ago and the fist thing I did was seek the best coffee in the area. This place roasts their own beans, creates amazing cakes and muffins and all in an amazing open space which feels great to be in. An all round great place to have or pick up a top coffee.
author: Luke L.

description: New blond girl is very rude. We wanted to put our points in and she just exited the screen and acted like it was our fault that she was so quick to make the mistake. Very bad customer service.
author: Stephanie D.

description: I walked in and the ambience was great. The service was quick and great. I ordered a Latte. However, I must say I was disappointed with the Latte. The milk to froth ratio wasn't good, there wasn't a nice consistency. Also there wasn't a really strong flavor or bitterness from the espresso, it tasted sort of bland. I worked as a Barista one summer and will only drink espresso drinks (except at Philz) so I sort of consider myself a Coffee snob. So I was disappointed. But the place is really pretty and cool.
author: John P.

description:
3 stars for ambiance (purely physical) and my delicious nutty cappuccino, and -2 for the blonde gal working on 8/24 at 6pm for service that can use some work.

I understand it's the end of the work day, serving so many types of people, blah blah blah; however, when one chooses to be in the service industry then isn't giving good (perhaps GREAT in Utopia) service what one shall strive towards giving? 

I love me a good cup of coffee, but it would be nice to be greeted when looking at choices and not just a lack of emotion or rather any human interaction.

Das my two cents and more.
author: Bern M.

description: I'm not a big coffee drinker, so I won't comment on the coffee. However, I thought the lighting was quite dark at places not near the windows and a bug also flew into my coffee :( Not sure if I would ever try studying here again.
author: Catherine S.

description:
Best coffee in San Francisco, and I'm new to the area so I spent the last hear trying all of the highest rated coffee shops on Yelp (Bereka, Philz, etc). This place made me never want to order a Starbucks again.

I remember walking in for the first time last year and asking if they had any flavored late's and the lady politely responded with "we don't have any flavors because the our coffee doesn't need it." I kind of laughed, but she was definitely right!

They usually have four different types of coffee (all in a jar at the register with the flavors/aromas listed, which makes you feel as if you're going wine tasting). Free wifi (can use both theirs and Whole Foods from next door). Free parking (I always park in the whole foods lot next door, and have never had any problems). The service is great (very knowledgeable and helpful). Tons of seating with an open, industrial but relaxed feel to it. 

I really like their Siphon Coffee. I'll pay the extra $2 just for fun experience of watching them make it the extra flavor.
author: Joey B.

description:
This is a great coffee shop. It's large and spacious with an industrial feel. There are seats inside and in the outside patio. The coffee ($3, ethiopian blend, black) was strong and aromatic, just the way I like it. Apparently the cold brew is awesome but I haven't tried it yet. The staff was friendly and efficient. 

The cons of Flywheel Coffee Roasters include a paucity of outlets (for all those who need to plug in their laptops) and shoddy internet (you have to register your email and it doesn't work half the time).
author: Nicole J.

description:
Scenario:
I went to flywheel last week with my friend. We were doing a collaborative work at the cafe. Here are some of my insights:

Pros: 
-good location
-nice cafe shop concept 

Pain points:
-you need to pay for the wifi after two hours
-not much light source
-coffee was just ok
-plugs are in an unreasonable place usually

*Would recommend to just hangout or meet with friend there than doing study there.
author: Minjie S.

description:
Bomb place for sophisticated coffee. 
Need that catchy by-line about you? Learn all about "Siphon" and "Nitrate" coffee at this spot, made using chemistry kits that even Heisenberg would be proud of. 9/10, would study here again. If one can secure a spot that is...
author: Gia P.

description:
I absolutely love this place. The coffee is great, the staff is really wonderful, they are extremely kind, caring and patient. 
HOWEVER, I think the one thing that a bit ruins my experience is the whole wifi issue.  
You only get access for 2 hours, and then get a pin code from the staff for another 2 hours. Those pins almost never work, or it takes forever to find one that does. 

It's a shame such a great place can't find better wifi connection options.
author: Ravit B.

description:
Siphon coffee - very cool to see very sciency looking process of making it. Flavor go the Ethiopian beans, it's supposedly "light and fruity" 


SERVICE
Order pickup at counter, baristas kinda seem too preoccupied to be friendly. Free wifi by hafta log in using email 


ATMOSPHERE
great open space industrial look with outlet and bathroom right by golden gate park and Haight ashbury with plenty of shops to meander through
author: Angela L.

description: This place is ok but there are no outlets outside which is annoying and the hot chocolate I ordered was too cold and there was milk "skin"  on top and I like whipped cream on my hot chocolate soooooooooo
author: Emma S.

description:
Beautiful space adjacent to the Golden Gate Park, and a perfect pick-me-up before or after your stroll. I know they're famous for their siphon coffee but I opted for my usual cold brew. The cold brew was quite good, fairly thick and rich, not at all acidic, and caramel-y and mellow, just the way I like it. 

I didn't get a chance to enjoy the space as I was on my way to work, but the large space is ideal to sip, sit, and enjoy if you have the time.
author: Kate M.

description: Love this place. Right across the street from golden gate, awesome coffee, and the best staff ever! Come grab a cappuccino or a cortado.
author: Paul S.

description:
This review probably isn't going to be too epic as I literally just popped in for a quick macchiato and to use the loo - but all in all the cafe was pretty cool, roomy and the right side of hipster without being too full of itself. 

I'm sure the stripped back design was cutting edge once but I really struggle now with a lot of independent places world wide going for the ultra minimalist, industrial vibe - I get it, it just doesn't excite me and I'm waiting for the next quantum leap in design to come (hopefully) soon!

Pretty spacious and occupying a cool spot next to GG park - it could be a good option if you want to get your coffee fix on when heading for a stroll.
author: Jonny Q.

description: Cool space and nice people. The coffee was bitter and pricey, and the wifi was so slow that I couldn't even load a speed test page. Tried to get some work done for about 45 minutes but it didn't get any better. Good place if you want a spacious hipster hangout, not so much for productivity.
author: Dan C.

description: Such a cool place to study. I've been looking for spacious coffee houses to study and relax at. This place is nicely decorated, lots of outlets, great lattes. What else could you ask for? It fills up quickly, but I would come here again way over Starbucks.
author: Jackie N.

description: Busy yet friendly. Chill cafe that has good simple coffee and pastries (good veggie quiche). Usually packed seating wise so easier to go.
author: Andrew C.

description: Meh. Ambiance is good but that's the only thing that will get me back here. Coffee was whatever - maybe a step below that. Bonus points for their utilities, but my cappuccino was poorly made and the baristas didn't seem to give a shit...in a bad way. Not in a "I'm a snobby hipster who actually knows their shit" kind of way. I might come again and give it a second chance but not if I have to go out of my way.
author: Cassandra A.

description:
oh my. Flywheel literally blew my mind with the siphon option this past weekend.  In need of finding a new place to venture out to, I ended up in the Haight where I got to see the remnants of Day 1 of the Haight Street Festival and the beginnings of Day 2. Flywheel has been on my radar for awhile now, but given how far it is from me in South Beach, coming out here was definitely a commitment.  Not one to shy away from an adventure, my husband and I decided to go with a few "non-traditional" items in ordering the Nitro Cold Brew and the Siphon option listed on their woodblock menu board.  We also had a blueberry muffin and a bran muffin to share.  While the pastries were just OK (not anything out of the ordinary from what specialized SF coffee shops are serving up these days), the coffees were definitely different from what I've had before.  The siphon process is time-consuming, so be prepared to wait awhile for this to come if you catch them during their busy time.  The cold brew has A LOT of caffeine and will chase away any notion of a hangover you might have after finishing their large Mason jar's worth of this potent stuff. But the siphon. I can't. 

If you find yourself here, stay awhile and enjoy people watching. With it being so close to Kezar and the park, there's absolutely no shortage of "interesting" things and people that pass by on the street.  Not only that, but Flywheel's cafe is beautiful, especially if you find yourself by the window sill. Amazing!
author: Lisa I.

description:
I thought I had been in some really hipster places before, but this one takes the cake.  The cafe is going for that modern-rustic warehouse feel, complete with fake barn doors and a lot of unused space.  The register is one of those iPad-based systems, but they encased it in fake wood for...reasons?  Not a particularly laptop-friendly place either, as other reviewers have noted.  Limits on wifi usage, which is nearly unheard of in this day and age.

Decor aside, the coffee comes in very small amounts and is very expensive.  Fine, clearly they put some work into it.  Whatever they do, it's not my taste.  The coffee tastes kind of bitter and fruity and doesn't go down well.  Just not to my taste, like the rest of the cafe.  Oh well.
author: Lars T.

description:
"I would love the blueberry muffin"
(serving with silent)

Tasting it- gross!
Letting my friend try- gross!!
The muffin stays almost whole.

... After a few minutes
"I'm sorry, the muffin is really dry, inedible"
"It is gluten free, that's why"
"Can I replace it?"
*no answer* 
**throwing the muffin to the garbage**
***walking away***
"You will just let me pay for something I did not eat at all?!"
*no answer*
Left the place. hungry.

Bad muffin. Horrible service.
author: Adi P.

description:
Great place! Natural wood, industrial metal, and black and white accents make for a truly chic ambience. A variety of seating arrangements make for a choose-your-own adventure with each visit.

The coffee is delicious, and an extra $1 will get you twice the shots (a quad!). As a caffeine fiend--or caffiend--I need a tasty cup of coffee with enough caffeine to give a horse a heart attack; Flywheel delivers!

Overall, a great business I look forward to continuing throwing my money at. Thanks for giving me a comfortable place to read or do my work!
author: Julien I.

description: Came here randomly with a friend, love the big open space and the plentiful seating. I had the mocha, it wasn't the best I ever had in my life, but it was solid. Just wish the wifi was better, couldn't connect to any networks at all.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Solid coffee shop where Haight-Ashbury meets Golden Gate Park.

This place roasts their own beans, which is something that even most third-wave coffee shops can't say these days. Flywheel has a large space with tons of space to study or do work, and definitely has the industrial look that defines so many coffee shops nowadays.

Parking is a bit limited since it's only street/metered parking, but there's also a Whole Foods next door if you're willing to risk parking in their lot and walking over.
author: Josh C.

description: Coffee creations just the way your taste buds crave with a great park side view. Helpful and knowledgeable staff!
author: Aviva F.

description:
There's two reasons that Flywheel is by far my favorite coffee place in the city.

1. THE COFFEE/SWEETS - Long story short, it's spectacular! They have a super wide selection of coffee with coffee beans from all over the world, and tasty pastries that are ALWAYS fresh.

2. THE PEOPLE - This one is big for me. Amazing staff, always reasonable. They genuinely care about the overall quality of flywheel (the place is always clean, lot's of tables w/Wifi, always asking feedback on the coffee they serve). Haven't been to many other coffee places that have such a great staff, with folks that truly care.

So all in all, I felt obligated to write this, so that other people can experience the luxury that I experience on a almost daily basis

...Just beware! Your tastebuds my burst upon first trial, I highly recommend that you prepare for a great experience.
author: Dean S.

description:
Unlike that Flywheel cycling class I went to, the Flywheel Coffee Roasters live up to the hype. I'm actually not sure if this place has any hype but it should!

Flywheel has a great vibe to the whole place. I dropped in on a Sunday evening. Most people were working independently or in small groups which I typically prefer since it promotes a productive environment. 

Service was solid and their pastries seemed popular. I was sitting at the counter so I could watch them make coffee during my stay. It's quite entertaining. 

When I go to coffee shops for the first time (and if you read my other reviews), I typically try 2 cups of coffee: the latte and a drip. Today was a little different. I ordered up 2 Siphons ($6 each) and a Nitro coffee ($4-5, I forget which). I've had both styles from several different places in the past. Both styles were very good and met my expectations. I will explain how each works at the end of my review I case anyone was interested. 

If you're visiting for the first time, I strongly suggest the Nitro coffee because it's basically a cold brew that offers a better drinking experience.   If you desire on the Siphon, you get to (or forced to?) choose which beans to use. I recommend the Kenyan because it has a nice, mellow flavor. If I were to go back, I would try the pour over instead of a Siphon because it's mostly a cool gimmick IMO. 

One criticism I had was that the wifi disconnects every 30 min or so without warning. It'd be helpful if they state that somewhere so I know when my google doc isn't being saved anymore. 

Bottom line is to check this place out of you like coffee. It's a good experience. 

OKAY, stop here if you don't care about the technical stuff because I'm about to flex some knowledge (hopefully, I say everything correctly). 

For the bean options, Your options are the Kenyan, a Costa Rican, and a Ethiopian. There's nothing special about these because of their quality to price point. They, or similar options, are roasted by most of the popular roasters (Blue Bottle, Sightglass, etc.). The difference is usually how the beans are roasted and the brew temperature and duration. I won't get into all those details but just know that how the beans are roasted makes this place unique, not the beans themselves.

NITRO: The process is pretty simple to explain. You take a cold brew, keg it, then use nitrogen to force the cold brew through a modified stout head (stout = beers like Guinness). No, the coffee isn't carbonated but it does have a nice bit of head / foam on top because of the tap. When you drink a Nitro Coffee, you'll first experience the light aromas in the foam along with the foam texture which will be followed by the stronger flavors of the coffee on the back end. I think the nitro helps bring out the flavors in the grounds but that could just be in my head.

SIPHON: Pretty much the same thing you do when you run out of gas. Just kidding. Okay this process is more sciencey version of a French press but it's conceptually simple. Okay, so there's an upper chamber and a lower chamber that are connected to be airtight. The upper chamber has coffee grounds in it while the lower chamber has purified water. As the water heats up in the lower chamber, the water has nowhere to go except to escape to cooler climates in the upper chamber with coffee. This is the "siphon" effect. The system continues to be heated while the coffee brews in the upper chamber. Once the coffee is ready, the heat is removed and the brewed coffee drips back into the lower chamber with the help of gravity. There's usually some type of filter in between the two chambers but there doesn't have to be. BAM, coffee is done. Now, let it sit for about 5-10 min for it to be at a drinkable temperature and enjoy. This process takes a long time but I probably wouldn't get it again from Flywheel.

Other notes: The barista told me the Siphon process removes the acidity which doesn't make any sense.  I'm pretty sure that the acid is reduced because of the longer brew time during a Siphon. This can be done with other brew methods. I'd probably just get a pour over next time and ask them to increase the brew time since  cheaper.
author: Chris W.

description:
I came here before Alice's Summerthing because it is located really close to Golden Gate Park. 

I love the interior of this place. It is fairly large and a good place to study or just catch up with friends. There is also a nice outdoor area, perfect for a nice, sunny day. 

I ordered a regular coffee and there were three different beans to pick from. I asked the cashier for a recommendation and I really liked the one she picked. The coffee was tasted really fresh and good. My friend ordered a hot chocolate and she really liked her drink. 

Inside the store, you can also see where they roast your beans. Very neat. I will be back!
author: Lydia H.

description:
Excellent Ethiopian Coffee! Hit the spot and was our favorite little place in San Francisco. 

Located right across from Golden Gate park.
author: Ali W.

description:
They have a great clean and open vibe inside.  The staff are really friendly.  I had the 15 our drip immersion.  It's similar to a Kyoto but the hardware is built by a different company.  

I like how they don't dilute the mixture.  My girlfriend had the mocha latte which was also very good.
author: David L.

description:
NIce place to hang for a cup of Joe.  Very spacious and not crowded. Reminds me of walking into a laboratory in a loft. Nice atmosphere and roomy for the workers too but it's a large piece of property.  Lots of folks sipping a cup of Joe with their Apple computers. 
Tried a cup of the latte, $3.50, nicely decorated with the leaf motif on top.
A very smooth cup of coffee upon first sip but the temperature was not hot enough for my liking.  Got 1/2 way down the cup and then the coffee went from smooth to bitter tasting and didn't taste as good.  Hard to understand why that is but my first couple of sips was heavenly.
Gave the rest to Hubby who drinks coffee by the bucket load and can't tell the difference between brewed and instant.
author: Ry T.

description: i'm only giving stars for the service, which was incredible. the barista offered me advice on what to get and where to go with a huge smile on her face. however, the latte (just plain because they don't have flavors?) was so bland and boring, even with the mocha they added for me. i couldn't even finish it. disappointed:(
author: Madison M.

description: Great coffee, great smells, great variety, and even greater staff. A shorter blonde man hands me a cup, smiling. I look down to see a medium cup of chocolatey ooze topped with a cream colored leaf. Its sensuous breath diffuses through my viscera invigorating all my senses. The first sip is soothing and exciting. The second only beckons me further. Third, fourth, I'm unable to stop down, down the level sinks as my spirit soars! The ecstasy is near unbearable, my system can handle no more! As my flight peaks, I notice a strange sensation: one I hadn't felt in what I believed to be an eternity; the elixer had ceased to flow. I softly settled back into my own skin, gleaned one fleeting moment to compose my expression from nirvana to its ease, gathered my belongings, approached the desk and asked "Another?"
author: Dan H.

description: This is my go to spot in the Upper Haight. The baristas are always super nice and friendly, the coffee is good, and they have great pastries. There is ample space, and if you're looking to get some work done remotely, you couldn't find a better spot. You get wifi for an hour or so, then you need to go up and get another code, but the rest of the experience makes it worth it.
author: Zack R.

description:
I've been here multiple times and my experiences have always been less than favorable, though nothing so bad that it's kept me away for good.

The space is cool, very modern with high ceilings. Think stark with some reclaimed wood and welded iron elements. I can see why some people would find it cold or off-putting but I actually like the space a lot. Definitely conducive to working or meeting up with people.

What I am not a big fan of, however, is the drink quality and prices. 

One of the first times I came here, I ordered a Yerba Mate Latte, for some reason assuming the quality would be higher because of its price and the general atmosphere of this place. I was unpleasantly surprised to see that it came from some weird premix you could get from Safeway or some such place.

The coffee and espresso, from what I can remember, is decent, though it's pricey and you really don't get all that much for what you pay for. Everyone walking around with Flywheel coffee to go is toting it around in this miniature 8oz cup.

The nitro is interesting, it's kind of like coffee soda, but unlike soda, it leaves a weird bubbly feeling in the back of your throat that doesn't go away immediately. Even a sample of it was enough to get me jacked, I can't imagine how people drink an entire serving of the stuff without having an anxiety attack. 

Today I came in early on in the morning and ordered a tea, which was Mighty Leaf, and was $3. Even if you're going to serve the most basic, easily acquired brand of tea in a fancy Bodum mug, it does not justify $3. Also, it doesn't allow much wiggle room for one to tip, which is something I typically do with service industry people. But I'm not about to slap down $4 for a cup of Mighty Leaf Tea.

The tea was served to me SCALDING hot (burned the very tip of my pinkie in an attempt to test the temperature) with no warning. I'm glad I didn't bump into anything or else I may have ended up with a 3rd degree burn, not even joking. 

I'm not sure what the appeal is to playing the most cheesy and explicit R&B/rap music at 9:30 am, but I'd suggest coming prepared with headphones.

After about 15-20 min of waiting for my tea to be remotely cool enough to sip, I was disappointed with how bland it was. It is beyond me why 80% of cafes and eateries choose to use this company for their teas.

So yeah, not the best place for tea or anything other than coffee (I can't speak to their hot chocolate or mochas). Though, their pastries do look appealing and are reasonably priced. I'll swing by again to try those sometime.
author: Megan D.

description:
This place would be an awesome coffee shop to hang out and catch up with friend. It has a spacious industrial look with awesome, complex looking coffee machines, high ceilings, and dim lighting.

For working, not so much. The internet is spotty at best, and requires you to sign in and post to your Facebook or to your Google+ for limited access. It also kicks you off after a certain amount of time, forcing you back through the process again. Probably not really the fault of the coffee shop, but it ticked me off a little bit especially as I needed a reliable place to cram some work out. 

Summary: Good place to get coffee and hang out. Bad place to get internet access.
author: Chen-Chen H.

description: The coffee is definitely overrated (very light, fruity blends that somehow always leave me wanting), but a great work space. You can order all of the various brewing methods (nitro, siphon, etc.), but I never am excited about the coffee in the same way that other SF go-tos do. So if you are looking for a great spot to chill by the park and get some work done, then go here, but if you're looking for great coffee then skip it. The staff is always very friendly and make some nice frothy designs.
author: Ali F.

description: One of the best of the best coffee shops in SFO! The staff is so friendly the ambiance and music it's super awesome and the coffee is just pure deliciousness my amazing Barista Fatima will make you the most delicious coffee drinks ever!! Definetly a must go to place in the GGpark area!
author: amy h.

description: The coffee was delicious and it was a very refreshing atmosphere after walking through Golden Gate Park.
author: Justina J.

description:
Flywheel has a store length area to laptop in. warehouse ambience.

drip pour choices: panama, brazil, ethiopian

pour: ethiopian  amran gayo drip(3)
-smooth but had a robust buzz to it.
-took some time to drip
3.5 stars, not the usual smooth  silky brew.
author: Victor G.

description:
Coffee snobs, rejoice. 

Here's a standard SF speciality-coffee place. There's an airy hipster vibe, with plenty of seating for folks who want to get work done. Roasting is all done in-house, you can see their giant roaster at the far end of the main room. There's also a small amount of seating in a patio area in the back. 

The coffee is excellent, they have a few different single-origins (I love the Ethiopia blend), and their espresso drinks are quite good. The staff are all coffee experts and can explain to you about how your artisinal so-and-so bean has "fruity" notes with "undertones" of "earthy" something something. $4 for a cup. If you're in the Haight and need fancy coffee, this is your place.
author: Bud P.

description: Passed by on the way out the park for a refreshing beverage. Ordered the "nitro" cold brew, i'm certain it was made with carbon dioxide and not nitrogen because it was sour and bitter with a bite like carbonated water. Went straight in the can, thoroughly disappointed!
author: Scott M.

description:
What a great coffee shop! Located at the edge of the Haight-Ashbury district and Golden Gate Park, it was a nice spot for me to sit down, get away from the hippies & tourists, and grab some coffee & wifi.
I'm from the east coast, where the coffee culture is strong, but nothing like the Pacific coast's. I tried the high tech siphon coffee, and it was awesome! 
There is plenty of room to sit, and I'd go back any time to sit some more.
author: Irina K.

description:
Cool little coffee shop across the street from Golden Gate Park. Nice concrete, steel and wood decor and fresh roasted and ground coffee.

Cabinet full of delicious looking pastries, but haven't had a chance to try them yet.

Cool and fast service and did I mention good coffee?
author: Bob K.

description:
My favorite local coffee shop. Great place to either grab a quick coffee or to hang out and get some work done.

Lots of different places to sit, from stools to tables with a patio outside. Perfect on a nice day to grab a coffee and do some work outside.

Free wifi and friendly staff make it an enjoyable place to keep coming back.
author: Jeffrey G.

description: Coffee is greattttt! This place is very calming and has a lot of open space. I gave this place four stars due to a healthy but tasteless blueberry muffin.
author: Rocio H.

description: Ordered two hot chocolates but they didn't have any mugs because it was so busy. We got to-go cups instead. The barista was really sweet and kind enough to make small talk about the rain as I awkwardly waited for my drinks so I truly appreciate it kind barista stranger. Hot chocolate was perfect to end the day of running errands on a rainy day as we sat on the seats by the window.
author: Nadine C.

description: Arrogant employee id'd as "the roaster ". Cold brew was extremely acidic and sour. Not enjoyable at all. As a "coffee snob" I found it undrinkable. I prefer small local roasters like Bicycle and Catahoula and found Flywheel cold brew sour and too acidic.
author: An N.

description: Coffee is great! But the internet blows. It's a huge pain to sign into, with the clumsy sign in screen repeatedly logging out you and making you log in again, sometimes right in the middle of entering your email or password. Plus there's a two hour time limit. Let's be real, wifi in a coffee shop is important these days, and it sucks here.
author: Brandon L.

description:
Flywheel, after four years, continues to be my favorite cafe in SF.  For working or whatever you want, the coffee is top-notch, isn't $4 like many places in SF, so you should like Flywheel.

The employees are super nice, they may be your friends if you go there everyday.  

The wifi works reliably, and you can use your comcast broadband account from home if you have it if you sit closer to the street.
author: John A.
