description: Love the coffee and the protein power bar. There's almost always seating here. Great spot to stop before a visit to the park.
author: Christa K.

description:
We came, we saw, we got turnt up on cold brew.

Though my friends say the staff can be iffy here (which apparently other Yelpers have also experienced), we had an awesome barista, who was prompt and polite. We both had cold brews (served in mason jars) and I had a decent croissant. 

I'd definitely come back and the industrial look of the joint is kind of perfect when you're over the stale ambiance of Haight.
author: Sam C.

description: Update: I got a nice note from the owner, who took responsibility for the drop in quality and explained how they were going to bring it back up. He also made a nice gesture of refunding my payment. I'm hopeful that Flywheel will soon be back on it's game!
author: R Y.

description:
Good espresso drink,  and I was impressed that they don't mess around with syrups (though I did ask for it on this visit,  which is how I found out). They have a number of other coffee drinks,  too, that look intriguing,. It appears they specialize in cold brew,  too, which I like.

The atmosphere isn't much for comfort - stark and concrete,  but trendy I guess.
author: Sam H.

description:
Very spacious, open coffee shop, with roasting in house in the back. 

I decided to sit in the back patio area, which, though small, was really nice. 

Coffee was pretty good, not the best I've ever had, but impressive latte art. 

Nice place to relax and get work done on a weekend, or meet up with friends
author: Marilyn M.

description:
Flywheel Coffee Roasters is perfectly situated alongside Golden Gate Park, with 2hr street parking, with some streets being free-all day (primarily meant for residents) if you can find an open spot!

It was a bit dark inside, packed with people on their Mac laptops. They do v60 as well as siphons, despite only the latter marked on their wooden menu board on the wall. Seems they really highlight their siphons, especially with the lighting on the boiler, eliciting a mysterious/magical vibe as they make them. Having siphon coffee in the past, the novelty is long gone, and I only consider it another legit method of brewing coffee (instead of finding it to be black magic). Compared to two coffeeshops in Los Angeles, they are comparable, making a good cup of siphon coffee.

The single origin I chose was alright. Nothing too notable about the flavors - a very balanced brew, not very acidic and just a hint of fruit.

Flywheel is alright. Want to try more of their single origins to get a better understanding of their roasting profiles.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Big open space with tables that are clearly not intended for a work-for-hours clientele: mostly tall tables without outlets and hard metal slippery stools. 
Noisy during busy times. 

So why is this not a middling review? You're here for coffee. And theirs is really first rate - the cold brew is complex and winey, and the cappucino is perfection. Not sure if they also bake their own pastries but they are good. Overall a nice chill spot for a tasty brew. Does not feel like it's just around the corner from the madness of Haight St.
author: Jenny R.

description:
Laptop camper here. Flywheel added free wi-fi awhile back and it's become a hangout for serious campers, the kind that stare intently at their laptop screens and barely move or blink. The wi-fi is a definite improvement but the food hasn't improved.

The main negative is that they still don't have many food options, just some pastries. The chocolate croissant that I had wasn't good. The lattes are still pretty good (bold, smooth) though the foam was too airy. 

There are a few outlets but not enough because of all the campers. The seats are uncomfortable but the campers are so hardcore that they seem impervious to discomfort. 

You know you love me. X0 X0, laptop camper.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Nice study spot. I'm always very productive here. 
Cappucino is exactly how I expected. 
The only negative side is that I can never get a hold of the outlet for my computer since it can get very crowded. But I guess they don't want people to stay for too long so it makes sense not to have too many outlets. 
Last time I came the coffee shop feels like a startup working office :) Everybody is glued to their computer, and a few groups talking over projects here and there.
author: Alan T.

description:
Uber.

Doing it wrong: wire.novaramedia.com/2014/11/fuckuber-8-reasons-why-uber-is-bad-for-all-of-us/

Doing it right: Ethiopian pour over with palatable respberry, vanilla and chocolate notes. So much so my stevia sat unopened and felt no need to inquire on nonfat milk. Well worth $3.

Enjoyed in an expansive space with clever branding nods (large wheels) and Edison bulb lighting. Pour over isn't the only option. There is serious caffeine chemistry lab action too.

While the WiFi is free wish there wasn't a cumbersome login process where you wonder if your data will get compromised. Otherwise a a great spot with a very friendly staff.

Flywheel is indeed awesome: http://flywheel.com/
author: Jason B.

description:
I came here to get a cup of decaf, they said they could do a pour over so I waited and checked out the surroundings. And this is why they even got 2 stars, because the place is really cool! They have a giant roaster in the back, huge bags of beans on the shelves, a cool table made of a large barrel full of beans in different states of preparation inside, under the glass table top. There are funky huge chains hanging from the ceiling, the lighting is very dim and comfortable (migraine sufferer here and it's hard to find a business that doesn't have raging neon tubes above your head) I was really excited to try their coffee!

I got my cup, went to put in sugar & cream and the area was super basic, some spoons, some sugar and a small open top metal pitcher of warm cream. I poured some in and chunks immediately rose to the top of my drink. I showed it to the guy who worked there who replied "It's warm but it's fine" but then showed his female coworker. This was really bizarre, she proceeded to drink some, declare it tasted fine, and was fine to drink. 

Umm, I had chunks floating in my coffee, that is not fine! She said she could remake it, but I said will all the cream be like this? The guy said it will be fine if I don't use cream, and she said I could use some milk from the fridge instead, But I just wanted a cup of coffee with non-chunky cream so I asked for my money back and left very disappointed. 

Then I looked around and saw about 10 people drinking something...were they all drinking chunky milk? Or does everyone there take theirs black? It's truly bizarre.
author: Venus S.

description:
I was so thankful to find Flywheel, because I'm from out of town and was on the hunt for a local roaster.  I automatically love a coffee shop that brews pourover, because it's a true act of love!  

I had never had a siphon brewed coffee and so I had to try it!  While it was $5, it was worth it!  It's such a unique brewing method and the employees were happy to tell me all about it.

It's a really open and inviting environment and I felt welcome to sit for a while and use my laptop.
author: Taylor G.

description:
My favorite Nitro brew in SF, and my favorite place to work from on Fridays. They have an awesome outdoor patio, with plenty of workspace. My only warning is that even for an avid coffee drinker, the nitro brew is serious stuff - I was buzzing for hours after (not in the heart-pounding anxious way, more so in the seriously caffeinated sense).

Add in the clean bathroom and sweet staff and you have a winning combo.
author: Ashley M.

description: The cold brew was strong, pretty acidic (not really my favorite), but complex and flavorful.
author: Alice C.

description: $4 for a coffee is a steep price to pay for standoffish and unhelpful baristas, slow internet that constantly loses connection and a dearth of outlets where I can plug in my computer that runs out of battery in 45 minutes. Let's just say I won't be coming here to work on my novel again in the near future.
author: Michael N.

description:
Flywheel! Cute, trendy little neighborhood cafe right next to Whole Foods and across the street from GG Park!

Lots of work space (and Wi-Fi), adorable little succulents on the table, and friendly AF baristas. 

Oh! And their coffee is really good too! (The cold brew. Must have. They also have nitro, which is twice as delicious and twice is deadly! Not for the faint of heart!)
author: Christianna G.

description:
Flywheel is the epitome of the type of cafe I have come to love. As a coffee/cafe snob, Flywheel emulates everything I miss from living
In Seattle. I can bring my dog in and grab a delicious cup of either Costa Rice or Tanzania. Maybe a cappuccino if I feel it
author: Paul G.

description:
I will say the ambiance of this place is great. There is lots of seating and it's definitely an open environment to plop down with a laptop for a couple hours. 

The coffee selection is also pretty great. I tend to like more mild, medium/lighter coffees that aren't too bitter and they definitely didn't disappoint. 

My problem with stems from my muffin. I ordered one of their gluten free muffins (I know, rolling the dice on that one to begin with but....). The first few bites were great--a great texture with a nice blend of flavors but the middle was just dough. It wasn't just a little undercooked, the middle was dough... Runny dough. So disgusting and definitely not worth the 3.50.... For a muffin
author: Elizabeth K.

description: Great Tea Bread and Cold brew here. I really love the small but yummy selection of baked goods :)
author: Keri V.

description:
Ordered two cold brews for total of $8. Wife and I both thought they tasted "off"
and she returned them to the barista, who disagreed. Barista asked if my wife wanted anything else. Wife said sure, two hot chocolates. "That'll be six dollars." Wife so shocked and surprised, she doled out the cash. The hot chocolates were good. $14 for two hot chocolates though? Really? We won't be back.
author: Darrell H.

description: Really loved the feel/vibe of this place if I was coming to chill or hang out with friends. But as a study spot, it's a little too dark and too warm, which made me sleepy/not productive haha. Their coffee is super strong though (milk/cream is a must)!
author: Jingxi Z.

description:
My favorite coffee shop in SF. I'm a fan of their Malawi roast. It's also great that they open at 6a, I stop by and grab my coffee every day on my way to work. The service is great. They're not like the typical snobby places in Mission. The coffee is as good as Ritual, Four Barrel or Blue Bottle. It's very nice inside too, high ceilings, lotsa space. The only downside is the Internet is not very reliable there. 

I want to say this place reminds me Coffee Bar in SOMA but serving better coffee as Ritual.

Oh you should also start collecting stamps, I'm going for my 5th free coffee. They use an app called Gving. 

Regarding food options other than pastry, there's Whole Foods right next to it. I don't mind going there, actually I prefer it that way.
author: Ertan D.

description: Guess we were in the place where all the startups hang out.  Genuine cool place.  Coffee knowledge required.
author: Dawn B.

description: Great coffee, ambiance, and outdoor patio. The best lattes are made by Fatima, even with non-dairy milk her lattes taste and look wonderful.
author: Ana K.

description:
Checked out this cute little coffee shop right off of Haight by recommendation of a friend.

Staff is very very friendly. I ordered a latte and the banana nut bread. The coffee was good, especially at the price. Most coffee shops charge around $4+ for a latte but Flywheel is around $3-$3.50. The banana nut bread wasn't dry at all (a lot of coffee shops don't care about their pastries let's be honest) so that was a pleasant surprise.

The atmosphere is so lovely! Everyone brings their laptops here to use the free wifi and work so it's pretty quiet. They even have a little area in the back out in the sun with tables outside.
author: Celina W.

description: Good coffee. Generally quiet sometimes the music volume is overpowering but decent music still. Lots of outlets. Cute outdoor area in the back.
author: L W.

description: Really great coffee here for what I ordered and at decent prices! Baristas were super cool and helpful in recommending options. I'd be back again for sure!
author: John I.

description:
I stopped by Flywheel Coffee Roasters while visiting San Francisco for the weekend because it was close to Golden Gate park and I was in need of a day break to relax, catch up with friends, and get re-energized for my touristy activities. 

While Flywheel was in fact close to Golden Gate park, it's quite hard to feel rejuvenated when its blazing balls hot in the establishment where you're sipping a hot beverage for a prolonged period of time. Look I get it - "San Fran's not used to the heat"... "it's an exceptionally hot weekend for September"... something or other about the drought... but if you can't get proper temperature control in a first world country then I'm going to be disappointed. As sorry as I was for myself, I felt worse for the poor staff dripping beads of sweat (probably in my coffee cup) for hours on end.

Besides being overheated, the coffee shop delivered in west coast style on all other fronts: espresso was good, service was great, and snack options were appropriately "granola". 

The seating area was a bit too spacious for my taste which stole a bit from the ambiance, but the industrial vibe was kind of cool and different. I was of course quite sad to see there were no couches available - probably a result of the coffee shop tailoring more towards student/worker clientele.
author: Tamra D.

description:
The coffee here is usually pretty good, however the last time went I decided to try the Kenyan drip coffee and it was way to acidic for my tastes. After taking only one sip I asked if I could swap it for the Ethiopian which I normally get and I was told I needed to purchase an additional coffee.

Having worked in the service industry myself I would never have made someone keep something they didn't like. It is simply good customer service to replace it. Considering nearly all places in San Francisco offer good coffee, customer service and ambiance are the only differentiators and I will take my business elsewhere.
author: Sean A.

description: Siphon coffee is excellent and totally cool to watch it being made. They have other cool methods of making coffee. Totally hipster place. But you should definitely give it a shot if are near golden gate park.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Love this place, have been coming since they opened and the owner is awesome.
James, not so nice on the phone otherwise really like coming here.
author: Ryan F.

description: Flywheel was fantastic!  I really recommend the syphon coffee.  Tastes great and is worth it if you want to share with your significant other or just enjoy some good coffee over a nice read.  I would recommend you enjoy a portion of the coffee while it's fairly hot/warm and then enjoy a portion that is more at room temp.  You'll get a wide range of flavors and bouquets this way.  Thumbs up :-)
author: Arman B.

description: Got the nitro iced coffee. Props to Flywheel for having a nitro, but it was extremely bitter. Not at all what one expects from a a nitro.
author: Scott H.

description:
Wow! Comparable to Four Barrel, which is my favorite SF roaster.

Got a sampling here of Hario Burner-made coffee, and marveled at the completely clean taste of the coffee. Would highly recommend buying that here, if possible. The pour-over coffee was fresh and aromatic. Friend got a mocha, which he enjoyed immensely. Glad we visited this location as part of our SF morning outing.

Baristas were chill and knowledgable, though felt that they weren't as friendly as the Four Barrel folks. This place did not have a lot of seating, and the setup is similar to Four Barrel, where there are few chairs and tables, and the lighting is mainly from the natural sunlight.

Parking by the Golden Gate Park is easy to access. Which is always the most annoying issue about going out in SF when you have a car.
author: Dianna D.

description: Flywheel Coffee Roasters is a top notch shop.  They're the only cafe that I've seen in SF that offers siphon coffee, so if that tickles your fancy you should definitely check this place out.  I had the pleasure of trying too Guatemalan's that they had on their pour over menu and they were both done very well. One was dark chocolatey with a nice nutty/nutmeg/cinnamon aroma and the other was lighter with more apricoty, fruity notes. Solid spot in the area and the outdoor patio area in the back was a great place to have a chat with some friends.
author: Nick F.

description: Flywheel has great coffee and pastries but when I went this morning the guy making the coffee kept going back and forth from handling customer's coffee to prepping the sink for cleaning dishes. He was using Clorox without gloves and then would go right to picking up and handing   customer's their coffee without washing his hands.
author: Dan V.

description: Flywheel is my favorite coffee place in the area. Good coffee and baked goodies, huge space with nice light, cool (small) back area. I like to come here to get work done.
author: Ryan Y.

description: Nice little place to chill, get some work done or just hang out. Drinks are good great quality, and the vibe is real.. Drink the cold brew and prepare for caffeine domination! 0.0
author: Dustin S.

description:
Very good place
Good location 
Use it for a chill with my friends before getting in the park.
Just perfect for a little rest.
author: Aviv H.

description: Great space, but unfriendly/snide employee behind the counter (she got upset when I asked to change hot tea to iced and later when I asked for cup with ice just stared frostily at me). The wifi was really frustrating with deal with. I really want to go back to this cafe but probably won't.
author: Jessica K.

description:
There's a lot to love about Flywheel coffee roasters. I come here frequently for early morning journaling sessions. I sit on the front benches, watch the sun rise over Golden Gate park, and tap out my thoughts on a solid wood bar table. The coffee is top notch - comparable with any high quality coffee shop in the city. 

That's the great stuff. On the not-so-great side is the food. It isn't bad, it just isn't particularly good either. On the plus side there are several vegan pastries if that is your thing. 

The worst part of Flywheel is that it has given in to our culture's ubiquitous need for noise. The music is louder than it needs to be, and the style is hit-or-miss - anything from 80s rock to grunge to modern pop. It would be nice to be able to quietly read a book paired with a delicious cup of coffee. But very few places offer that experience, so I can't deduct more than one star. It's still a great place for a morning stop if you find yourself near GGP.
author: Jacob L.

description: I use to go to this coffee once per week the coffee is good the place is nice to study bit the big problem are the waitress . None of them are smiling or being polite ... Too sad for a nice coffee house
author: Laura B.

description: Had a nice cappuccino here, and a very mildly sweet blueberry chip cookie. Feels like a good place to work at, and others seem to agree, given how most of the seats were occupied. Have yet to go out back to their patio. They get a view of the sun setting behind the trees in the park.
author: Linus W.

description: I'd come back. I stopped in for a quick coffee and the first time I was here I was quit confused where to pay or even order. However, It's a neat place. Love the interior and also they have outdoor seating which is even more awesome.
author: Julie L.

description:
I've only been here once, but I mostly liked what I saw.

The pourover coffee was really good.  There were three good choices of beans.

NICE tables.  Solid, non-wobbly and comfortable seating.

Nice light and open space.

Sadly, the pastry selection seriously sucks.  Don't arrive hungry.  Seriously, it was the saddest choice of pastries I've seen at a cafe in a long time.

I will be back, but I'll make sure I eat first.

Hoping to upgrade my review in the future.
author: Leon S.

description:
I really want to give 3.5 stars. It's the quintessential SF hipster coffee shop. I was also irked they charged me 50 cents for hot water when I had my own thermos (and she wasn't that nice about it either.) 

Their coffee is pretty decent. I'd come back if I am in the area looking for caffeine.
author: Sneha P.

description:
Good cafe.  Great ambiance.  Awful wifi.  Like, the worst free wifi I've experienced in a cafe in San Francisco.  It for some reason needs to reconnect every few minutes through the ridiculous vendor service.

Don't come here to work, unless you don't need wifi, or have your own provider situation.
author: Bodhi S.

description:
Haight, the final frontier! These are the voyages of the San Francisco dweller... His mission? To explore strange new localities, seek out the authentic and original, and to boldly go where no suburbanite has gone before! 

It seemed that this dweller had almost given up hope... Yet another boring replica coffee shop, "burrito" joint or bakery?  I was starting to think this planet we call 'San Francisco' had lost it's way to the corporate evil empire (yes, I am mixing SciFi, bare with it!). It seemed no more independent unique places were opening anymore!

Whispers about a new neighborhood coffee shop, in place of the old (San Francyclo, they moved to Arguello) bike shop got me intrigued.
 
I get on my Specialized bike (hand-made in Morgan Hill), snap on my All-Star's, and find a vest...Socks pulled over my skinny jeans, I look like a 30-something wannabe hipster.  I change into my boot cuts, and put the bike away, I've almost killed myself every time I'm on this fixie! 

The Space:  BIG, industrial, concrete interior with wood pillars, with lots of space to breathe!  Reminds me of a large loft, Huge windows in the front facing GG park with narrow bars on either side of the entrance with metal stools.   They're opening the patio in the back soon, and the interior is super clean.  They have Wifi, you just have to ask for the info.

Food Selection: A handful of fresh croissant, cookies, banana-nut bread, and alike.  They make their own (grandma recipe I'm told) banana nut bread/pudding, it's crazy good, but just not for me! Remember, I'm a cyclist!   In the little open-fridge area are cups of fresh cut fruit, goodness.

Drinks: The fridge has a bunch of cold drinks, from peligrino to Vita Coconut water and fresh OJ.

Coffee:  I order a dry cappuccino.  I get exactly that, and the coffee is really *delicious*.  They also make fresh single cup coffee, a-la-blue-bottle style (we all know they started it!).

Welcome FlyWheel, Live long and Prosper, and invite more of your species to our little Planet!
author: Mark K.

description:
Post industrial minimalist interior (dark hardwood walls and floor), hipster pour over coffee, some "ok" pastry selection, free wifi, a guy working on his typography in Illustrator, a dog or two, and right by the park.

Great place to come and get some work done and be seen typing on your macbook air!
author: Andy J.

description:
Lorenz L is spot on, if not a little more tactful than I.  "Take their coffee seriously", Exactly.  And as if to emphasize this they have camomile, and a couple of other fruity blends for tea as options.  I would have left were it not for my friends that wanted coffee.

More importantly, a motorcycle just outside was leaking gasoline.  Thinking it might be one of their patrons, I informed the cafe owner and the two others working, only to get a laugh and a rude dismissal.  I later had to go outside to tell someone smoking to stand clear of the motorcycle.

Gimme a break guys.  All you do is serve coffee, as if anyone gives a flying f.
author: K G.

description:
Pros: Great pour over coffee that is reasonably priced for SF, nice ambiance, places to stand while you work

Cons: I really want to review this place favorably since the coffee is good, and the place is nice. I used to come here to work, but the wifi is difficult to log into and has been really slow.
author: Marc C.

description:
I'm not a huge coffee aficionado so I can't speak to just how good the drinks here are compared to the other places in town, but it was definitely good.  

What I love most about this place is the large, open spaces. It's just what I want when I go to a coffee shop.
author: Rowena L.

description:
5 stars for great beans that I usually buy to go and make drinks at home. 

I'm a big fan of how nice it feels to sit in the big space and smell the coffee roasting.

The latte is done well, sweet milk often with some good latte art to go with it.

For any one in the area, you should make a visit here.  It's on par with the rest of the third wave of coffee in San Francisco.
author: Tony T.

description:
Stopped by after a long bike ride over the Presidio with a stop to admire the Andy Goldsworthy sculptures.

After around 3 hours of mostly-uphill activity, all we wanted was a decent espresso, a nice snack and maybe some friendly service.

Flywheel failed to deliver on all fronts. Well, at least they have one thing going for them: consistency.

Let's talk service. Good service is when you look a customer in the eye, smile, answer any questions politely and cheerfully before actually rendering a service in exchange of currency. We did get our lattes eventually, so I guess they understand the last part of the concept but the rude, almost-hostile young woman who took 'care' of us added an extra shot of bitterness to the already bitter coffee for us. She could not be bothered to tell us what the available pastries were and seemed irritated when we asked what was in the pastries. Hey "lady", some people have dietary restrictions. Also, knowing the name and ingredients of the pastries sold at the coffee shop where you work isn't a trade secret. Sharing them with customers will not violate your NDA with Apple/Google/Tesla. We ended up ordering just 2 lattes because not a single person behind the counter could be bothered to actually tell us what was in the food items.

The lattes when they arrived were decent enough. Nothing to touch something from an Intelligentsia or any other really good coffeeshop but not so bad that we couldn't drink it. I was surprised that they actually roast their own beans because the flavor profile was flatter and staler than freshly roasted beans should be. Maybe they save the old beans for out of town visitors along with their crappy service.

The space is actually quite large for San Francisco and there is plenty of light in the front through the big plate glass windows but the layout of the counters and tables is weirdly inefficient. Not that I care. I don't plan to ever go back to this place but you might if you want to work from there.  

Maybe we just weren't lucky or Yelp is not as reliable as it used to be but we found most higher end coffee places in San Francisco to be lacking in one department or another compared to places in Chicago, Seattle, Portland and yes, Atlanta. Only contraband coffee in Nob Hill seemed to have the magical three part formula down pat: good baristas, good coffee and a welcoming atmosphere. 

Flywheel, you have the honor of holding up the other end of the spectrum. Hey, at least you're not lost somewhere in the fat, middle part of the curve.
author: Buddhi G.

description: The chocolate macaroon was absolutely fabulous but the coffee was awful; very bitter and the beans had been over-roasted.
author: Geoff G.

description:
They use Martha Brothers' coffee, which confuses me because I thought they are a local coffee roaster.  I'm guessing I was wrong about that.

Service was not good. I asked if green tea lattes worked with soy and the cashier was hesitant and unsure if there was even any soymilk. That is fine, I understand that this place is new.  

Check out my photos for the curdled green tea latte. I notice that this happens  every single place that uses kirkland signature soy milk to make tea based lattes. 
I can't find another way to contact the owners so I hope they care enough to keep up with their yelp reviews and contact me to refund the $3.50.

A huge plus by the way: they use Square!
author: Anna T.

description:
Since their invention in 16th century England, coffeehouses served as centers for the intellectual pursuits of the commonry: writing, reading, talking, debating, etc. Coffeehouses were and remain retreats away from home and family (and children). At no point in their five hundred year history have babies been welcome inside. Babies DO NOT belong in coffeehouses.  They are not welcome and their parents shouldn't bring them. They belong in coffeehouses as much as they belong in theaters. 

Although Flywheel gains a star for addressing the heat issue, they lose it for the recent influx of awful hipster parents and their noisy hipster baby spawn. It is almost impossible to relax and read or to write an email when a baby is nearby making *loud* baby noises. I come here to escape.

And, minus one more star for the phone policy, OF WHICH THERE IS NONE. The last time I was here, a woman started a Skype call on her laptop. She was so loud you could hear her at 100 paces - but, lucky me, the idiot woman sat down in the empty chair at my table. Yay! I got to listen to her mindless yammering for twenty minutes.  I know you read this, fellas: PUT UP A SIGN. Make it a policy!

----------
UPDATE:
----------

I haven't seen any babies that last few times I've been here, so you get that star back.

The service has always been pretty good, but lately it's been white-glove perfect. What happened? Plus one star. 

CELLPHONE TALKING STILL AN ISSUE.
author: Tim W.

description:
I've been to this place a ton! They have a small list of coffee options, but all the right ones. They can make the hot options iced which is great and they offer almond milk which is rare in the city. They also have at least one vegan snack option most days.

The coffee is good, although it can some times be a bit acidic. The vegan snack items are hit or miss. Some days they are fresh and some days taste stale/dry.

There happens to be a lot of people who park in the cafe for hours to work from their computers... any/every day. It's a funny sight to walk in on the weekend and see a row of people along the wall sitting working from their Macs.

Overall, it's a good place to sit and enjoy a coffee for a while.
author: Scott C.

description:
Great coffee, terrible service. 

Asked for a capp, got a latte. Mentioned something and got the biggest, most unnecessary attitude.
author: Josh P.

description: I love this place. This is where I started to drink Siphon coffee couldn't stop. They have a big open space which is great for students trying to work. They also have a small patio outside if you want air. Their coffee is unique to their name and its really good. The baristas are also very knowledgeable about their coffee. My favorite drinks include siphon, latte and mocha. Their mocha is the best I have ever had.
author: Yushi C.

description: I was visiting from LA and this was my first time at Flywheel. I ordered the Costa Rica Dota Valley with the siphon method because I had never had it before and I didn't quite like it. It seemed to make the coffee taste much more acidic than I thought. BUT, THEIR ICED LATTE WAS DELICIOUS! I would definitely recommend getting the iced latte because it was one of the best I've ever had.
author: Marissa D.

description:
Great coffee shop. As a breastfeeding momma, I'm always on the hunt for decaf. Most of the coffee shops in SF can only provide decaf espresso drinks, but these guys offer a tasty pour over with a decent decaf roast. It's not the best decaf I've ever had, but it's definitely in the top 1/3. Small tastes of my husband's Ethipian and Kenyan (preferred) were also good. 

Good baked goods too- not a huge selection, but certainly comprehensive.
author: Karla R.

description: Was a terrible experience. Came here on NYE ten minutes before closing time and it was obvious they were keen to close and finish off the day. Coffee latte art was nonexistent and coffee was shoddy. I'm not sure if this is their usual standard but I think my money would be better spent on Starbucks.
author: Joanne L.

description:
I was on the hunt for a perfect cafe for studying in San Francisco and I think I found it!  I was used to having a huge selection in Seattle ( but then again we are talking about Seattle) and was almost disappointed by the selection of cafes with a good study environment near the Sunset district. However, I am in LOVE with this cafe. Here are the reason why: 

- Free wifi
- Free parking ( 2 hour in certain areas, but it does get frustrating on Fridays) 
- Delicious coffee 
- Quiet
- A handful of people who are studying/ working just like me

+ if you need a study break, you are right next to the Haight
author: Jennifer L.

description: Overpriced, uncomfortable decor, mediocre coffee and bad wifi. They make you confirm your email address before using the wifi and then it's slow. This place is everything that's wrong with modern SF coffee shops, it makes me sad...
author: Bishop J.

description: Flywheel is a great spot for a coffee date in the Haight. They first opened when I was moving out of the neighborhood, so I never got to try it! Last week my friend and I decided to meet up in the Haight and ended up at Flywheel. Neither of us had been before and we both really enjoyed ourselves. First off, I love the atmosphere. The cafe has a nice modern feel to it and they play excellent music. Kudos to whoever sets the playlist! The latte art was also gorgeous and the coffee was very tasty. I will definitely return next time I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Rachel S.

description: The cold brew is good and the space is great. But the employees? When I asked about if zucchini ricotta pastry (surrounded by sweet pastries) was sweet or savory, the shaggy-haired white guy who works Tuesdays at 3pm said, "I don't know." Then the blond woman with the same haircut  as the guy said, "It's okay." I said, "Savory?" She said, "Yes," as if being inconvenienced. I said, "Is it made without sugar?" she said, "Yeah." Again, as if my question the cross she must bear. I decided to skip it as I  didn't want to pay $5 for a tiny circle of pastry one person didn't know and the other said was "okay." When it came time to pay, the I asked the male employee to remind me of the App they use for frequent buyers. (I had at one point before moving come here more frequently). He said Sqaure. Thinking that he was telling me what POS system they use, I said, "Which App do I have in my phone that lets me track my purchases?" He said, "I have no idea what you have in your phone." Condescending customer service never works, guys!
author: matthew d.

description:
Having moved to San Francisco from Australia finding somewhere that can do espresso right has been quite a task. Flywheel is one of only a handful of places I've been to that has managed to nail it.

Aside from the great coffee this is also a good place to set up and get some work done, with a comfortable ambience and a great little back deck. Definitely one of the best places in The Haight to get espresso.
author: Benjamin C.

description: I agree with another comment about the importance of consistency. Tonight, I ordered my usual and got a drink that was slightly off. So, I will stick to coming during the day. There's a barista who makes great almond milk lattes but I only see her during the day.
author: Anmay K.

description: Nitro cold brew coffee is killer.  I seriously felt like my heart was going to beat out of my chest.  It's pretty strong and did it's job.  I had the coffee at 730am and still feel wired at 8pm at night.  The space is nice and open with plenty of outlets.  Great place!
author: Tammy N.

description:
Tried the siphon coffee after deciding to grab some coffee with a friend. It was neat to see how the barista made the coffee! So, for $5, I was expecting a pretty darn good cup of Joe, and not to my surprise, it was delicious! The taste is light and not overwhelming and in addition, there were no coffee aftertaste you would normally get after drinking cheap coffee.

The atmosphere was also a plus - a great place to study!
author: Edgar G.

description: Love this place! If you lucky enough to have Fatima make your froth for your desired coffee drink, you'll have a great day! She is a Jedi Master of baristas. Thanks Fatima! You rocked my mocha today!!!!
author: Linda L.

description:
Jesus Christ the bad reviews of this place are snobby.  2 stars because you don't like the seats? Get over yourself. 

Good coffee. Good pastries. Warm service. Sunny seating.  Would be my go to coffee shop if I lived closer.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
I received condescending customer service here. One afternoon I ordered an iced coffee and tried to connect to the WiFi network.

WiFi was down, nothing was working. I tried restarting, turning it off, double checking the password. Still not working. 

I walked up to the staff and said, hey I think the wifi is down, any chance you could please reset the router? 

Instead of checking it out they said, "Well the music is still playing so it means the wifi is working. Try it again."

I tried it again. Still not working. I came up a second time and asked them to please consider resetting it, it should be pretty easy to reset the router.

In a condescending way, they asked me if I really knew whether I was connecting to the right wifi network and typing in the right password. Are you serious?

This made me so upset. I am a software engineer. Of course I know how to connect to a wifi network and type in the right password! 

I sat down back in my chair, deflated. The guy next to me said, "Hey you're right. Their router isn't working." 

I went up and asked them to reset it one more time, mentioning that the person sitting next to me confirmed it wasn't working. They said, "We'll look into it," but as I sat down and watched them, they didn't do anything. It wasn't even busy, there was nobody in line.

I packed up my stuff and threw my untouched coffee away. I was supposed to meet a friend here, so when it was time to meet, I asked her if we could go somewhere else. I am not coming back and will not recommend this cafe to anyone.
author: Erin P.

description:
Love this place. It's just so freakin' good. In my opinion, it's the best coffee shop in the city (which is saying a lot for a city that boast over a thousand) and it's only a half block from my apartment! Win-win. 

Okay now full disclosure....I don't drink coffee. BUT I do love a decaf latte/mocha so I can speak to that. It's just so rich and smooth! Also, my fiancé is a big coffee drinker and he agrees with this rating, so there. 

They've added a pasty display somewhat recently too - they didn't used to have any sort of food - and although I don't think it's house-made the tasters I've had are really good. 

The one mark against Flywheel in my book is the lack of chai latte. I love my chai lattes and Flywheel used to make one. In fact, it was potentially my favorite chai latte in the city! (See a pattern here?) Then, one day, poof - all gone. I didn't realize 'til I tried to order it and they were all like "we don't have a chai latte". I said, "but you just had it the other day", and they said "now we don't". Ugh. Next time I came in, I asked why they no longer served a chai latte and apparently it's because it was the one thing on their menu that they weren't involved in the making of (meaning it must have come from a mix or syrup) and so they nixed it. I get the philosophy, sort of. 

Anyway, these days I go for a decaf mocha or a hot chocolate. Both delish.
author: Lindsey B.

description:
Friendly local spot.  Four out of five only due to very limited hours (come on, guys, why close at 7;00 PM?)
Coffee quality = 5 stars
Ambiance = 5 stars
Staff friendliness = 5 stars
Snacks = 4 stars
Parking - nonexistent in The Haight... Natch
Bonus tip- Whole Foods next door.
author: Matt W.

description:
This place makes a great cup of coffee, from a regular cup of java to their mochas and cold brew. 

Cold brew is awesomely well-balanced and does not require sugar or milk. Mocha is not too sweet but chocolatey enough. 

Flywheel will always hold a special place in my heart - where my boyfriend and I had our first date - and we will keep coming back for the memories and the delicious coffee!
author: Liz G.

description:
Flywheel is my go-to coffee shop in San Francisco . Their coffee is fantastic and they roast it in-house. To decorate they leave some of the roasting and brewing machinery on display, going for an industrial chic type look. The place reads strongly on the yuppie/privilege/first world problem radar, if walk through the door and you're liable to see at least 10 macbook pros in a row. That having been said I feel many of the best coffee shops I have been to in my lifetime exude a similar vibe. 

Having mentioned their interior decoration and clientele I would be remiss in failing to mention that their coffee is FANTASTIC. The Kenyan Blackberry in particular has an exquisite bitterness to it I had not previously encountered in a drip coffee. Their lattes are on par and their mochas are downright unforgettable. For an additional fee you can have your coffee "cold brewed", meaning no heat was used in the brewing process. They have some interesting-looking devices that cold brew these batches. Coffee is served at the perfect temperature to drink immediately, no waiting for a boiling cup to cool down. Price is about standard for an upscale bourgeoise cup of joe.
author: Tomas K.

description: This place is great! Really nice atmosphere, modern and rustic with big windows and plenty of table space. Most people are there to work (as was I) so the environment was energizing and I got a lot of stuff done. They have a selection of Mighty Leaf teas, I got a black vanilla tea that was great. Only problem was finding a place to sit (due to lots of people, not lack of tables) and figuring out the wifi. It required email verification and the link didn't work, so I ended up having to work on something else. Guy behind the counter knew so much about coffee, gave me valuable info I'll be able to use elsewhere. Cold brew was good but a bit too sour for me.
author: Anon Y.

description:
This coffee is too strong for me. Love the ambiance; concrete and woodsy, makes for a comfy place to WFCH (CH: coffee house) The staff could stand to be nicer. 

TIP: Make sure to ask for little ice in the ice coffee or they will give you a cup of ice.
author: Jenn D.

description:
First of all - their coffee is delicious. As a former barista who went through extensive training in Seattle, I can tell you they're definitely doing it right when it comes to espresso. They have a small assortment of pastries which are by far the best coffee shop pastries around.

HOWEVER they are seriously lacking in customer service skills. I went in on a not very busy weekend  afternoon with a few friends who were extremely excited about trying their delicious coffee and left thinking I would have been better off grabbing a terrible latte at Starbucks instead. The man taking my order was rude and snobby and when I asked for the pastry labeled "crumb cake" in the display window he picked a fight with me saying that I was reading the sign wrong and that wasn't what the pastry was called...even though the sign clearly read "crumb cake" and everyone in line with me knew it. Even when he pulled out the sign and realized it was wrong he just played it off and didn't even apologize for basically calling me stupid in the most condescending way possible. Then the man who was ringing me out had the rudest attitude going on asking me what my order was again and acting like I was wasting his time by even being in the shop. 

The whole all-male staff that was working that day were a bunch of rude, snobby, condescending employees. All of my friends experienced and you could tell that everyone one else ordering was just hoping to get their coffee and dive into their MacBooks or dive right on out the front door. 

For such a cool atmosphere in a large space with great coffee you wish that it would be more inviting and that the baristas working there might be a little happy to be working there. 

I probably won't return again just to avoid the unfriendly staff. Who wants attitude served to them with their coffee?
author: Jordan M.

description:
Serious about ya coffee? You should probably check out Flywheel!

I admit, i love me some goooood coffee, but i sures hell aint a connoisseur! That, left me feeling a bit 'lost' in this spot, but damn that coffee was good 'n strong!
author: Seven T.

description:
I've been eying this place every time I swing into the worlds smallest WFM. 
I never saw signage or anything to indicate what they were selling. I rightfully assumed it was a coffee joint, when I observed people sitting outside with their cool Bodum coffee glasses. 
I love coffee and I totally dig this place. Spacious and airy, they are definitely working on more space in the back and possibly seating in the upstairs balcony. 
The coffee is outstanding! I only order drip coffee but it is amazing. Strong and flavorful but not bitter or burnt tasting. I've tasted burnt beans and this place does not serve them up. With free wifi and reasonable prices, Flywheel is a winner in my book. 
Just a word to those in a rush, you will wait 5+ mins for your drip as they hand brew it. So don't bitch if you're waiting a while when they're busy.

Lovin' this neighborhood Java house!
author: Eden F.

description:
This place is great for hanging out or working. 

Here's why:
- Really good coffee.
- Great background music.
- Friendly staff.
- Outside seating.
- Free wifi.
- Power available.
- Relaxed atmosphere.
- Hipster interior design.
author: Josh D.

description: Excellent cup of coffee. The atmosphere is great. And the price was reasonable. Good place to get a later to walk around the park with.
author: Kristopher A.

description: Wish the workers were more kind. Coffee is fine, but the hipster vibe is nearly intoxicating. For a more normal, welcoming vibe, I suggest Starbucks.
author: Tim B.

description:
Gosh, guys, you really hurt my feelings. I LOVE your matcha latte with almond milk. It's the reason I walk past five coffee shops to get to yours. I appreciate you for many reasons (almond milk, a variety of coffee options AND matcha, delicious baked goods, a cool space where I can always find a seat, etc.), but today was really a bummer.

I don't mind waiting. Good things come to those who wait, after all, but it was more the bummer attitude today that put me off. After I wait twenty-five (or TWENTY-NINE to be exact) minutes for a drink, I don't need you to give me a 'tude. 

Here's what happened: I ordered my drink right after another girl ordered the exact same thing. They hadn't taken our names or anything, so I double checked as I was ordering and confirmed with the cashier that I would wait to hear a second matcha called. She appreciated that (yes, I really AM that responsible and considerate). I waited the usual ten minutes, saw the first girl take hers, and then grabbed the next one. As I was turning to leave, the guy shouted after me, "Wait, did you want almond milk?" Thinking he was about to apologize for almost giving me a tummy ache, I came right back, ready to reassure him that it wasn't a problem. But no. He said, "I didn't say that one was almond milk." Okay, no big. You guys are busy and stressed out. I'll wait. 

He then proceeded to make four more matcha lattes without so much as a glance in my direction and passed them off to these other girls. The only explanation I can think of is that they had forgotten their order even before I had come in. I FINALLY get mine, and he says sorry, then I smile and say, "That's okay--I'm sorry I took the wrong one!" Then he looks at me, nods, and gives me a yeah-you-should-be glare (was that an eye roll as you turned away, bro?). Geez.

I was trying to be easy-going about it, but you guys were just A-holes back to me. Not nice. If you mess up an order, don't take it out on the other customers.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Best coffee in the Bay Area. 

They're Ethiopian is roasted to perfection and the taste is just divine. To be honest I do not know everything about coffee and I would definitely not consider myself anything even close to a Barista. My boyfriend on the other hand is a full time Barista and Roaster at Augie's Coffee in Redlands and he could not believe how amazing the coffee was here. He even went on to say that it was better than both Four Barrel and Rituals coffee and believe me he knows his coffee well. The more I tried the coffee the more I could taste the difference in flavor and roast. The people that work here are also extremely nice and knowledgeable when it comes to the products that they are selling. I do not have a single complain or critique about this place. The space is just wonderful and I love coming here to read or doing any work I need done on my laptop. I love this place and I will be a long time customer.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Classic and swanky hipster coffee shop. High ceilings, large windows, warehouse feel. Truly a beautiful cafe. Topped off it's got a good amount of outlets and wifi so is an ideal spot to go work for the day or just for a few hours. The back patio is the best mix of outdoors but sheltered from the elements so you can work/read/talk without getting too cold with ridiculous SF weather. 

Bigg downside for me is that they discontinued their chair - shux :/
author: Milan T.

description: I don't drink coffee, but the hot chocolate is delicious here, with a visible gradient on the side of the cup from dark chocolate to creamy drink to thick white foam.
author: Letitia L.

description: This rating is for the people working here. They are seriously rude! Also, I tried for 30 minutes to get their wi-fi to work. It never did.
author: Eva M.

description:
So far flywheel is my favorite coffee shop in the city. 
I'm picky about a lot of things.  The coffee first most, but also the environment if I want to hang out.  This spot gets my approval on both points.
author: Bobby D.

description:
I love this place!  My friend described it as "A library with music and coffee," and that's basically what it is.  The music and coffee are perfect.  I like how the light filters through the large windows, and how there's an outdoor space in the back.

Three things need to be fixed:
1. More outlets
2. The toilet is horrible - often broken and whenever you flush it you're just praying that whatever you put in there will go down.
3. The roasting machine noise is really bad.  It feels like an icepick in your ear.  Run it when people aren't here.
author: Mark W.

description:
Quality of the food/coffee 5/5
Atmosphere 5/5

Wifi 1/5... Impossible to connect after 30 minutes trying... Really frustrating!!!
author: Dimitri S.

description: The flavor was sour without the complexities.  I found a possible explanation...   "Excessively sour flavor in your coffee brew is a likely sign of underextraction, i.e. the coffee has not brewed long enough and has an excess of acids. Acids are extracted early in the brewing process, whereas other balancing flavors are extracted later in the process."
author: Debbie L.

description: Randomly found this place, right near the park, was pleasantly surprised. This place is very welcoming, chill atmosphere and super hipster. So hipster that you will be amazed by the number of glass devices used to make all kinds of drinks. I tried Siphon coffee and it was great. Takes little bit of time, but the process is picture-worthy. There's also a coffee roasting machine right in the back that's constantly roasting, so you will love the fresh smell of good beans. Loved this place, wish I could stay all day, but that might bring a heart-attack. Ha!
author: Vladimir G.

description: I've been back a couple times since trying out the cold brew to see if the hot drinks are any better.  This is definitely where flywheel shines as the couple lattes I had were rich and flavorful with perfectly made microfoam.
author: Russell S.

description:
I've tele-commuted from dozens of cafés. I really enjoy Flywheel's coffee, work-supportive atmosphere, amiable staff, and decent wifi. Also, Flywheel makes a damn good mocha.

I just moved to this neighborhood and plan to come here often after my summer travels. Thanks for creating such a fantastic atmosphere for us, Flywheel team!

If you're in the neighborhood and are into coffee and environments-in-which-work-can-get-done, I also strongly suggest checking out Stanza on Haight.
author: J'aime O.

description: I wanted a latte but they don't have nonfat milk. I ordered an espresso instead which cost $3. Quite pricey and not that great tasting: very sour and sharp.
author: Will N.

description: I ordered a latte and a biscotti. Both were great. The espresso has a great flavor and is not at all bitter. Nice design in the foam cap. Biscotti tasted fresh and was a good size. The place is very industrial with a lot of the original fixtures and wood beams maintained. Lots of seating but still feels spacious. All around a great coffee house.
author: Karen C.

description:
Why do you not have a sign?  It is the craziest thing.  Flywheel has been open for 2 years and, despite having a large fixture for a sign attached to the exterior, it is blank.  Occasionally they have a bi-fold sign standing on the sidewalk outside (there's a picture of it that another Yelper took), but that's it.  Crazy to me!  Met a friend for coffee at flywheel today.  She lives around the corner from Flywheel and had no idea it was even there.  Front door wasn't even ajar so exterior looks very unwelcoming.  Lack of signage / open door = loss of 1 star.

However, the rest of the review is glowing.  Beautiful urban interior with re-purposed wood.  Flywheel roasts delicious beans, and the latte I had was exquisite.  The music playing was a pleasant surprise, kind of "cool classical."  There are a few communal tables and a good number of 2 tops.

A great coffee shop located next to Whole Foods on Stanyan.
author: Penny P.

description:
Update:  I hate to see it happening...there are more and more computer camper-outers spreading out and taking up space.  

The back patio is great, except for the fact that the neighbors are doing some kind of construction that is loud and smells of gasoline and sewage.

Great coffee, a good atmosphere.  I'm not sure what the outlet situation is, but when I've visited they haven't been completely taken over by computer users, so there's room to sit and hang out or read a book while you enjoy your coffee.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Nothing special about this place, other than it is an independent coffee roasting company. Coffee is standard, and the pastries are good but can get heavy since they come in big portions.

I made the mistake of sitting out on their back patio, hoping to enjoy the sun. LIttle did I know that the back is covered like a greenhouse, making it unbearably hot! I would come back to get my caffeine fix, but that's it.
author: Shikha K.

description:
There are two things that make this place stand out for me:

1) The space is pretty industrial, spacious, yet modern. 
2) The staff is incredibly nice.

Me and a few classmates were in need of a study location on a Sunday afternoon. Where could we find a place to speak that also had reliable WiFi? Flywheel Coffee Roasters turned out to be a great decision.

One of my classmates ordered a chai latte which she mentioned was perfect. I just got some tea for $2. They didn't have a great selection, but this is definitely more a place for coffee.

I don't often go to Haight, but if I do, I'll keep this place in mind as a stop to rest and study.
author: Paul B.

description: Great coffee shop and roaster. I had a Tanzania peaberry poured over V60 preparation. Their tasting notes were accurate. I also had a really tasty muffin. The space is large and spartan. In contrast to other reviews I thought the service was friendly and efficient.  The staff had good coffee knowledge without being overly pretentious.
author: Reno H.

description: The best latte I've ever had! I wish you had more locations! Or one on so cal. Such amazingly delicious coffee . It was like I had never had coffee before. Your staff was friendly and efficient. Great place!
author: Lisa N.

description:
Came in hoping to find something like Philz, maybe even better.  That didn't happen.  My expectations were way too high.

We got two coffees.  They start their Chemex on each when I notice they use water at 212F.  Not sure if that's normal, seems too high for brewing.

Tried both coffees, and not much depth of flavor.  It was coffee, but can't say much more about it.

Yes, I saw the roaster in back.  Yes, it was an individual pour over.  These two parts that should make this a unique gem just aren't combining well.

And I also agree, more can be done with this space.  Sure, industrial and minimalist, but I like hanging out in a coffee shop, not an abandoned factory.
author: Matt C.

description:
I popped into Flywheel after a leisurely stroll through Golden Gate Park and was pleasantly surprised. Flywheel is a great, well-designed coffee shop in the Haight.

The coffee was great and there were plenty of tables (although when we went they were full of macs, headphones, the occasional notebook, and intensely focused people).

A warm, inviting space - high ceilings, very industrial look. I bought some espresso beans to bring the flavor home, but will definitely be back here whenever I'm close to the park!
author: Ashley T.

description:
Could've fooled me. Genius Bar (Apple Store) or coffee bar? Based on the line-up of laptops, patrons basking in the glow, who could tell the difference?

The lesser connected customers instead basked in the glow of the afternoon sun filling the front window seating, the only spots sans computers. Likely the only area without outlets. The decor of the place could be described as industrial or minimal; think: wood + concrete + laptop 

In an attempt to catch-up with a friend, we grabbed beverages, but were without luck finding a place to sit. You know those laptops don't move and the sun blazed so hot in the only few available window seats, we took it to go. Unfortunate, but thankfully Golden Gate Park is right across the street and walking through the park with a warm beverage is never a bad idea.

The cold brew was good and the cappuccino was okay, but nothing special.

If you're looking for a place to park your laptop, you're likely in luck.
If you're looking for a relaxing place to chill out, chat, and enjoy your beverage, I'd be happy to recommend somewhere.
author: Alissa A.

description: It's not the coffee, it's the wifi. Buying a coffee isn't enough to get online. One also must give them an email and agree to be spammed, then verify the email. BUT EVEN THATS NOT ENOUGH. The link in the verification email times out. You're still not online, and you get spammed. It's probably easier to hack into a government server than get online and work at Flywheel.
author: Jessica H.

description:
An all-around disappointment, and that's not something I level lightly. I came here based on the raves for the coffee and the location/space itself, figuring the low reviews were outliers--but they seemed to be pretty on-point. 

The place itself has a completely standoffish, sterile vibe. It's not warm and welcoming, despite the design touches to the contrary (the now-cliche warming Edison bulbs, wood paneling, the outdoor patio area), and the day of my visit the counterstaff wasn't either.  The space is very roomy, spacious even, but there's a lot of it that is unused. The layout doesn't allow for much communal interaction, either. I had expected to see a lot of laptops based on other comments but was surprised at how many there actually were--just about everyone had a laptop flipped open, as if it was a requirement to be there. I was there to meet with a friend and have a conversation over a cup of coffee but the vibe just didn't feel right for this. 

I had some rudimentary inquiries about the coffee available, expecting them to sell me on a particular varietal/region. The "third wave" coffee 'trend' is all about nuances of flavor from different regions and styles of roasting, and it seems at most places I've visited even if they don't roast the beans they will share some impressions of what they're brewing with some semblance of enthusiasm. Not here. I received the equivalent of a "meh" and a shoulder shrug in the guise of 'we hope it's good'.  Come on, people, get excited about what you're serving!

As I was planning on staying in I didn't expect to see them pouring my coffee in a paper cup. But as soon as I realized they only had plastic mugs I immediately recanted. Plastic? Who does that? Outside of the kiddie cups at a family restaurant I don't expect to be served coffee in a plastic mug, period. Even the low-cost greasy spoon has ceramic mugs. They need to do the same. Especially when they're charging premium prices for their slow-drip brews.

And the coffee itself? Meh.
author: alejandro p.

description:
The people that work here are friendly and the coffee is quite good.
I had the yirgacheffe pour over and that went quite nicely with the pastry that I had.  I only gave it four stars because it's not necessarily my favorite place in San Francisco, but it is one of the best ones that I have been to.
author: Johnathan W.

description:
I came here on a Sunday morning around 11AM. This is a nice little place that's right on Stanyan, across from the park. It's right next to the Wholefoods.

This place is pretty spacious and has a few seats with outlets. There's also a few seats right in front that's facing outside towards the park. The front seat would have been good if I was just reading and enjoying the sun.

There's an upstairs but don't think it's for customers. I sat right in front of the area where they make coffee and it was nice seeing the workers make pour over coffees right in front of you. 

They have a few selection of pastries right at the register but once they ran out, it's all gone. I wanted to get a biscotti but the person in front of me got it. They use an ipad to take orders.

I got a regular latte in a glass cup. It was good but didn't have as cool of a design as I've seen on Yelp. I noticed that they also sometimes take names of people's orders but they didn't ask for my name when I ordered. Also, the latte wasn't super hot and was easy to drink right when I got it.

The wifi worked well here and I didn't lose connection or have any spotty connections. Great place to get work done.

Overall, I really like this place and would come here again to get things done. Great location and has a nice seat that looks out to the park.

Pros:
-Nice window seat view
-Very spacious inside
-Outlets for computers, good wifi connection

Cons:
-Lattes wasn't super hot
author: Paul U.

description:
Great atmosphere.
Packed with laptops.
Limited plugs.
Cool coffee makers.
Experienced baristas.
Good Coffee (but sharp).
Almond milk.
Lots of GF and Vegan treats!!!
author: Krish K.

description: Went into Flywheel after a stop at the Whole Foods Market next door and WOW! What great coffee. I love the cold brew at this place. Topher and Fatima are also very great.. will be back! :-)
author: Fayth Y.

description:
I can't remember how many times we've had bookclub here but holy hot damn, do they have tasty pastries!

I always wash it down with a hot chocolate- which never burns my hand thanks to their nifty mugs. 

Nice spot.
author: Loli L.

description: Cool spot. Great coffee and pretty spacious - I've always found a place to work/study without a problem.  Staff has been pretty friendly as well.
author: SinGlu V.

description: Great spot. I loved the look and feel of this unique and pretty large coffee shop. There were numerous options of seating (indoor/outdoor- table for 2, table for groups, bar, high tables etc) however it was a bit crowded so I ended up sitting where I wouldn't initially prefer. There were just enough outlets (at least by the high table, didn't see any near the windows) and the wifi was great. The pastries looked amazing and the service was nice enough. I noticed that the people/customers were friendly as well. The bathroom was pretty well kept and the prices were reasonable. Will definitely visit again.
author: Kristy F.

description: The place has good coffee, and the deco is good. And I really think that the 2 hours renew pin code thing is smart, and I think it is very reasonable. But I would prefer that the staff don't tell me in front of every other customer loudly that I need to buy something after two hours as if I was trying to steal the wifi. I can't drink too much coffee, so I ask is there any non alcoholic drink. And maybe that is not very good either? So she point to the fridge and instructed to me to feel free to take a look at the juice...I mean i need internet, but I am not beggar.  You know I think it is reasonable, and I will make the purchase, cuz I do need the wifi. But just the experience is not great. I think maybe just me, because I don't go to this place often or because I didn't smile to the staff there?  And maybe just that staff? Cuz I look a little embarrased standing in front of the counter when she said that. And the other staff were looking at me kinda embarrased too? It was just a little weird... but overall good coffee. And they do have wifi. It worked. So I am still very thankful.
author: Flora Q.

description:
Iced coffee? Divine.

Staff? Kind and helpful.

Prices? Rock bottom.

I chanced upon this cafe on a trip through San Francisco with a friend and was immediately drawn in by its modern yet rustic interior. We shared an iced coffee in the rear, outdoor area and chatted over a magazine. The space had such a great atmosphere (if not lacking some greenery), but after about 20 minutes, we felt some rude stares from the people around us. We were not talking very loudly, but talking in the coffee shop rubbed some of the patrons the wrong way.

Most if not all the people in there were in their mid-20's to 30's, typing away on their Apple laptops. This could seriously be the most productive coffee shop I have ever seen.

The cafe is great! We loved their coffee and interior design, but we will bring our work with us the next time as to not be rude to other patrons.
author: Yolanta S.

description: Delicious lattes and chill atmosphere. Love also that they write your name on the bottom if your mug.
author: Marc H.

description:
Good coffee, but pretty small service size for dining in. The pastries (particularly the tea cake) was fantastic and I would go back just for that. The back patio was finished, and had some nice wooden tables and benches to sit on. Slightly on the smaller side but nice none the less. 

I would recommend trying the pastries and the coffee is alright.  Great location, next to golden gate park and Haight- Ashbury. 

Go if you're in that part of town.
author: Laura D.

description: Great open space and friendly service. Regular complaint of mine, soy latte not so good. 1. Either the soy is overheated and it burns or 2. The milk type isn't meant for high temps.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
What a wonderful addition to the upper Haight.  There isn't another cafe like this in the area.  I only wished it opened a year ago when I was living there.  I love the exposed air ducts and minimalist decor.  
They roast the beans on site and unlike other roastery's they are affordable.  I paid $3 for a latte which is almost unheard of these days.  Plus, the coffee was phenomenal!  Thank you, thank you!!  I will be back!
author: Molly M.

description: I love this neighborhood coffee shop--terrific pour over coffee, great tea cakes (especially the morning glory tea cake), and nice cold brew.  It's also a great spot to sit and work, or chat on the outdoor patio.  Definitely a great hangout.
author: Alisha H.

description: The pastries were tasty but better yet the coffee was super good. The place itself has a cute atmosphere with plenty of seating.
author: Anastasia R.

description:
Their internet rule is a complete scam. They go by 2 hour increments, where the first 2 hours is "free" and you get 2 hours for every coffee that you buy. At least that's what I was told when I arrived. It turns out the first 2 hours is "free" and the first coffee you buy "doesn't count". And the barista waited to tell me this AFTER my first 2 hours were up. 

TL;DR If you have work to do, find a different place.
author: Prashant R.

description: Great coffee and really nice ambiance. They make drip, expresso as well as siphon coffee. Siphon is sooo smooth but it takes awhile so don't get it if you're in a hurry.
author: Karen C.

description: Great lighting, no couches - yummer tea.
author: Denise M.

description: The coffee, espresso drinks, and pastries here are fantastic.  The ambiance is a bit sterile, the seats are uncomfortable, and I always get the vibe that the staff would prefer that I wasn't there.  This is a good place to go if you want to work on your laptop, like everyone else.  It's not really the best place for a chat with a friend.
author: Jessica L.

description: nice place and great siphon coffee
author: Armin P.

description:
My go to place for getting work done!

I love the coffee and espresso here!
I love the lay out of the place!
I love the benches!
I love the little back patio, even though I never really hang out back there.
The staff is friendly! Super friendly!
I enjoy the staff and they enjoy my doggy and I believe that they enjoy me. :)

(I think the owners could probably lighten up a little. I personally think that they have a little bit of an attitude towards specific customers, not exactly sure what their deal is, but whatever I still love me some Flywheel!)
author: Jasmine S.

description: Delicious drip coffee in a calm and relaxing setting. I can see myself choosing this coffee shop as a new work office.
author: Andrew Y.

description: I dont remember being impressed with the coffee, but this place is very cute.  pretty spacious and nice, and seems like a great place to get some work done.  love that they have a small back patio
author: Lisa H.

description: Their lattes are excellent and their staff is friendly. The ambiance of the venue is calming and I love to spend a few hours working on my laptop. I just wish it didn't get so crowded all the time!
author: Karina L.

description:
I live down the street and they have quickly become my favorite in the city.  They roast in house, love the coffee, staff is very friendly, and they are relatively quick as compared to other coffee shops.

My vote: Hope they quality stays as is for time to come.
author: T P.

description: Come here for the coffee. They serve it by single pour over and they have espresso drinks too. They also have a cold brew system too. The chai was delicious. They have some delicious, overpriced pastries too. They use Bodum double walled drinkware. The place is discreet, industrial, but comfortable somehow. Depending on who you interact with, service can be either friendly or pretentious. Want to fit in? Bring a Mac.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
let me begin by saying that I am VERY particular about my coffee. Also, this review is soley based on the roasting skill and price of Flywheels whole-bean products. I grind and make my own coffee daily (multiple brewing styles) and buy 1/2 pound of fresh roasted beans weekly. Purchasing weekly ensures that my beans are always extremely fresh and full of oils and are,attics that are lost over time.
Flywheel usually has 3 varieties of bean available at any one time. My 2 favorites are usually roasted on Mondays and Tuesdays. Without fail, the beans are always roasted to perfection (usually a "medium" roast) and is always finished based on what is best for the bean. The cost of $16 per pound is amazing for this quality. I have compared EVERY roaster in the city and Flywheel wins on price and quality. Others may have more variety, but charge nearly double for their beans and either don't have the consistent quality or ability to sample the aromatic product prior to purchasing. Flywheel is a winner in my book, and I always kick myself when I choose to try another roaster. I always come back to the best. Thanks for the great product!!
author: Moses A.

description: Coffee doesn't get any better than this. I mean seriously, these guys are experts. The baristas treat the coffee like it's a science experiment. They have it down to a formula and will not settle for anything less than perfect. I used to think Velo Rouge was the spot to be at on the weekends, but Flywheel takes the first place trophy now. Great ambiance -- kinda reminds me of Four Barrel in the Mission, but Flywheel is more spacious and has a great neighborhood feel. I recommend the cappuccinos, peanut butter protein bars, and Morning Tea Cake -- altogether.
author: Linda T.

description:
A trendy, warehouse-inspired cafe 

The Costa Rica drip was wonderful. They had that and several options from Kenya. Hot drinks are served in double-walled cups- what a great idea. Not many food options besides a few pastries.

The seats are spread out, which makes the space feel very open. The trade off is that there are not that many seats alltogether.

Parking can get difficult around that area and alot of noise from the traffic on Stanyan leaks into the cafe. That alone will makes me reluctant to come back.

Free wifi and power plugs.
author: Alfred L.

description: Flywheel opened quietly two days ago, occupying the former bike shop adjacent to Whole Foods.  Neighborhood coffee lovers already have many reasons to be pleased:  Flywheel's delicious coffee, warm and responsive service, and spacious interior.  On top of this, in a few days they will be roasting beans onsite, once all of the site improvements are finished.  I found the coffee to be on the bold end of the spectrum and I imagine the beans roasted onsite will also be bold and flavorful.  I highly recommend the iced mochas and iced lattes, which were a perfect complement to a warm afternoon stroll.
author: Chris T.

description: Second time here: they take coffee very seriously here - maybe too seriously. Last time coffee was decent and the autistic service a novelty. This time their attitude was annoying and the espresso unpalatable.
author: Lorenz L.

description:
4.5 STARS
--Coffee is delicious; moreover, unexpectedly, a mere $2 gets you a great hot chocolate.  And I am very picky about the quality of my hot chocolates.
--The line-up of coffeecakes and loaves is also very tempting.
--The exposed wood, and art on the walls, creates a soothing, pleasing, tasteful atmosphere - great for relaxing or studying.
I'm here literally every week, I like this place so much.
author: Yekaterina M.

description: Love the looks of the place and also love the coffee, but the staff has never been very friendly.  If they were I'd give it a 4 or 5 because the space is really beautiful. Today when I ordered a protein bar with my coffee it was totally frozen, like I couldn't even bite into it.   Although she did refund me, there was no apology.  Basically was just told that they just took them out of the freezer. Obviously!  So my suggestion in the future would be to wait for them to thaw out before selling to your customers.  Just saying!
author: Coraly S.

description: This place is a gem! They roast the fresh beans every morning. I am addicted to the cold brewed iced coffee and its a great place to get fresh green juice.
author: Chris P.

description:
Power outlets: how long will these last, maybe a year or two? Coffee Bar has 'em, but none of the other third wave coffee shops do.

Nice space, they're still building it out. I talked to the owner about a month ago, and he said they plan to open the back loft, and add a roaster. As other reviewers have said, the space has a Sightglass/FourBarrel feel.

The espresso isn't great. It has a slightly burnt "left-it-in-a-pot-on-the-warmer" taste, and is lacking the faint sour, acidic tartness and complex notes that the coffee snob in me prefers. At least they know to make a strong americano ($2.75) by default. Instead of an italian porcelain cup, they put it in a double-walled Bodum glass, which works well. I assume the coffee will get better once they start roasting their own.

The price is a little high but you're paying for the power plugs. I believe a Sightglass americano costs the same; most places charge 10-20% less ($2.25- 2.50). (Duboce Cafe takes the prize as the worst deal in SF for a $3 watered down americano in a 10 oz. glass mug, and they removed their power outlets years ago.)

But you know, once everyone gets a 10-hours-on-a-charge iPad, then those outlets won't matter.
author: Tom P.

description:
Great quiet, productive atmosphere. Great for getting work done. Several outlets. Tech/startup/hipster/young crowd. Free wifi that is fast and usually reliable, drops out sometimes. Clean bathroom. No bums or hippies come in to stink up the place.

Drink-wise, everything I've had has been stellar. Iced tea is refreshing and comes in a variety of flavors. Coffee blends have nice, smooth, fruity flavors. Best coffee in Haight-Ashbury and second only to Philz in the city. In my opinion.

They take their time brewing your coffee right, so don't expect to run in and be back out in 2 minutes. It doesn't take too long, depends on how busy they are, but it does take longer than other places I've been. Definitely worth the wait :)
author: Jordan G.

description: The space is great but the coffee is offensive. Flywheel's aspirations are obvious and create high expectations -- but what you get is a cup that's consistently worse than freezer-burned Folgers Crystals.
author: Andy B.

description:
We've been hosted by two very nice women. One ran in the behind to get some oranges when I wanted an orange juice (she suggested a fresh squizzed juice when I was just thinking I'd get a bottle). She filled a full pint of that squizzed juice. My GF ordered a pecan pie and a tea. She enjoyed both a lot.
It cost us $8 only. Kind of a great deal. Our hostess have been smiley and nice to us. The manager talked a little with us about our stay in SF.
That's a place which deserves a visit.
author: Arnaud W.

description: The building itself is gorgeous and so is the ambiance. I wish I had good things to say about the coffee...but the Kenya coffee blend was too sour for me. I winced every time I took a sip. I don't like to add too much half and half to my coffee but adding more than I usually would to my coffee couldn't salvage the drink. Sorry but I don't think I'll be coming back anytime soon.
author: Annie S.

description:
